column8: Wonderful rainforest experience - not to be missed
column11: I took a full day trip to the Sinharaja Forest reserve, with Cinnamon Bentota Beach hotel-based naturalist Thisara Kuruppu last weekend. This is not to be missed. Thisara is a trained naturalist and really knows his stuff, especially the birds but also mammals, reptiles etc. His English is excellent and he was very good company on the drive. It is a 2 hour drive in an airconditioned car (with a separate driver) to the reserve, along very good roads through pretty countryside and rice paddies and and gradually climbing past tea plantations. The reserve entrance has good parking and clean toilets - and a few resident Blue Magpies, a species unique to Sri Lanka. This was a taste of things to come. We picked up one of the local villagers that is employed by the reserve to take people into it (included in the price, but who I tipped). He found us all sorts of interesting things (some photos below): flowers (eg orchids), MANY butterflies and other insects, trees and shrubs, lots of birds, several different lizard species, a snake, frogs, squirrels, monkeys. Many of these are species unique/endemic to Sri Lanka. Between the 2 guides I learned an awful lot. The walking is easy going along very good paths - concrete at first (to all for vehicular access) then well-tended paths through the rainforest. Leech socks were provided along with water. I took a few cakes to eat as we were out in the reserve for a good 3 or 4 hours. The forest has a wonderful calm to it, it felt totally safe and I enjoyed the company. I highly recommend this trip to anyone with an interest in the natural world.

column8: Sinharaja Rainforest - A haven for rare Flora and Fauna!
column11: Whenever I visit my home country Sri Lanka, one of the first places I visit is my favorite nature reserve: The SINHARAJA RAIN FOREST. We stayed 3 days at The Martin's Lodge which is the ideal place to stay overnight if your purpose of the visit is to experience the wonderful nature and wildlife at the Sinharaja. The accommodation is quite basic but more than adequate for the avid nature lover with running water, electricity and spacious rooms with bedlinen. I had met Mr Martin several decades ago when he was a guide of the reserve. He was someone who had contributed immensely toward conservation of the forest and the species. After his passing, his family is running the lodge and they are very hospitable and provide the visitors with very good service and delicious Sri Lankan meals. A 4x4 vehicle is required to arrive at the lodge but the location is then only 5 minutes from the entrance. There is a lovely view of the forest and the surrounding area from the dining area and a fruit feeder and the gardens attract several species of Sri Lanka's rare endemic birds such as the Blue Magpie, the Yellow-eared Bulbul, the Spot-winged Thrush, the Square-tailed Bulbul, the Jungle Fowl and the Spur Fowl. This hilly virgin rain-forest, part of the Sri Lanka lowland rain forests, was once saved from a disastrous commercial logging in the 70's. Then it was designated a World Biosphere Reserve in 1978 and a World Heritage Site in 1988. I have been visiting Sinharaja for over twenty years and I have had many wonderful sightings of some rare birds of Sri Lanka over the years. Sinharaja being Sri Lanka's primary tropical rain-forest, most of the Flora & Fauna here are endemic and this is their final refuge. This time, among the rare and uncommon birds we spotted, the Serendib Scops Owl, the Green-billed Coucal and the Red-faced Malkoha were unforgettable sightings. May these endemic birds that are found nowhere else in the world but in the rainforests of Sri Lanka, prevail for long!

column8: A lot has changed for the good: no more motorcycles!!!
column11: I had the tracker legend Bandula as a hiking guide, he is brother of Palietha, both for their part the first to popularize trekking in Sinharaja, both studied biologists, therefore very adept, knowledgeable. Compared to several years ago, much has changed here for the better: Motorcycles are no longer allowed to cross paths, which was unfortunately allowed at the time. column8: Ecotourism, great food, great service and well worth the bumpy ride to get there.
column11: One of the highlights of our trip to Sri Lanka was Sinharaja Forest Reserve.  It was an hour in a jeep on a  very steep, rough road to get 8 km to the ecolodge but so worth it.  Sri Lanka is trying to develop its wildlife conservancy and National Parks and this area is a biodiversity hot spot of international significance which has been designated a Biosphere Reserve and World Heritage Site by UNESCO. The ecolodge accommodation was clean, but a little worn. Don't expect room service or luxurious accommodation, there are no televisions. The limited a la carte menu options were very good. When we stayed the lodge did not have a license allowing it to serve alcohol but our driver warned us ahead of time in case we wanted to BYO. We did some gentle walks during the night and day. The area apparently has leopards, civet cats and fishing cats but we only saw their droppings and claw marks in trees. We saw monkeys, deer, frogs, other invertebrates, loads of birds, waterfalls, old growth forest and pools filled with fish which nibble your feet. Some of the communal areas were being revamped whilst we were there but this was not in any way intrusive. It was a very peaceful stay, fairly basic but if you love rainforests and want to support Sri Lanka's fledgling eco tourism industry you won't be disappointed.

A hike in the Sinharaja forest is clearly worth the detour for anyone interested in nature, because the humid tropical environment is very different, in the scenery and in the fauna present, than most of the rest of the natural sites of the country (more in dry forest). I very strongly encourage you to accompany the guide Hemal, an extremely passionate and exciting young man whose language barrier was not a problem. He will be able to share with you his extensive knowledge about the forest and its inhabitants whom he knows by heart, with great kindness and availability, adapting to your pace and being very attentive, particularly in repelling the numerous leeches. We did a day hike as well as a night hike right next to the reserve and it was a real pleasure each time. Reptiles and amphibians enthusiasts will be delighted at Sinharaja but you can also observe birds, primates, invertebrates, etc. A big thank you to Hemal for this discovery which we highly recommend.

We (family of 4 from South Africa) visited Sinharaja on 28 February 2022, and stayed overnight at the Kurulu Ella Eco resort, right on top of the mountain. Had a pleasant stay at the resort that had a waterfall right in its own back yard, and then arranged with Danushka to be our guide in the rainforest trek the next morning. He came with a safari jeep and driver, picked us up at 8am and we entered the reserve by about 9.30. The road up was quite windy but extremely scenic. Entry into the Reserve was a breeze. Inside we were given our leech socks that covered till the knee area, and shoes were sprayed. The hike was amazing, we covered two of the three waterfalls, and were given a good explanation of the plants and animals we encountered. The dipping of our feet at the waterfalls was a tingling sensation as the many small fish nibbled on the skin. The rocks were very slippery and even though we had good hiking shoes, they did not grip on the wet rocks, so we had to be very careful. After 4 hours we were back at the jeep and exited. Had a memorable day there. Leeches still cling onto your knee high socks and shoes, and we got used to removing them with our hands as we saw our guide do this. If you did get stung, they suck your blood, you feel some pain but it is not fatal, so not to worry about these parasites too much. Best to do in morning, as it rains almost every afternoon. You cannot hike on your own and must engage a registered guide. Estimates of cost for 4 persons inclusive of entrance fee, guide, safari jeep, leach socks and spray was 12800 rupees for 4 pax which I thought was reasonable, other guides charge more. Happy to recommend Danushka. He can be contacted at +94 77 100 5329 (Whats app), or +94 77 525 4486 (tel)

However, the height of the forest canopy as well as the thickness of the vegetation makes it quite difficult to spot wildlife. Moreover, unlike in other national parks in Sri Lanka, access to the forest is only by foot, guided by a trained ranger.

On my first afternoon we birdied around the village . Our first bird was Serendip Scops Owl quickly followed by another I endemic Sri Lankan Rufous Babbler . Other sightings included : Hanging Parrot , Small Barbet , Pale-billed Flowerpecker and Indian Pygmy Woodpecker . Early next morning we entered the forest, glad to be on foot  after a steep bone shaking jeep ride . Our first new mammal was the curious Purple-faced Leaf Monkey followed by another selection of great birds , including : Spot-winged Ground Thrush , Legge‚Äôs Flowerpecker , a pair of Frogmouths , Ashy-headed Laughing Thrush , Malabar Trogon , Velvet-fronted Nuthatch  and Black-rumped Blue Monarch . However the best two birds took a long time to find . Firstly we followed a small track into the forest and made our way slowly and quietly through the undergrowth and crossing streams until we gained clear views of the elusive endemic the Sri Lankan Scaly Thrush . Secondly following advice from a local guide we retraced our steps and left the main forest following the call of our target bird high in the canopy . After much neck breaking scanning of the tree tops we finally had sight of the Red-faced Malkoha . After lunch we changed out plans to return to the Heritage Centre in search of the Sri Lankan Blue Magpie as our early morning visit was disrupted by a large group of school children . However there were still dozens of excited children around , then after an hour the heavens opened . Finally we did see a very bedraggled Blue a Magpie and Layard‚Äôs Squirrel . Early next morning we drove up to Martin‚Äôs Rest , one or the first specialised birding accommodation in the forest . Where we had breakfast on the balcony overlooking the forest . Just before breakfast we saw our final endemic bird , White-faced Starling . Thank to a Upali my guide I had now seen all the 34 endemic birds of Sri Lanka . After more birding we returned to the Heritage Centre and were rewarded with excellent close up views of the spectacular Sri Lankan Blue Magpie , plus Oriental Honey Buzzard and a beautiful Forget-me-not butterfly . Late afternoon after lunch we took a steep trek up a winding track in search of roosting owls . However after a strenuous climb we were unsuccessful but we did see a Brown-throated Needletail flying over . On our final morning we entered the forest for the last time and although we saw few new birds I did get clearer views and photographs of birds seen earlier , such as : Dark-fronted Babbler , Ashy-headed Laughing Thrush , Sri Lankan Crested Drongo , Spot -winged Ground Thrush , and one until now elusive bird Slaty-legged Crake . After a refreshing drink of tea with a local family we finally walked out of the forest . 3 days which I will never forget .

As I didn‚Äôt find enough instructions and what to expect while searching I thought of writing the review with all the details included which I got to know from our guide and I assume it will help the future  travelers. Excuse for this long review though. The best time to visit this rain forest is during January - Mid of April. If you‚Äôre interested in birdwatching it‚Äôs better to start at 6.00 a.m (Opens at 6.00a.m) but as the birds fly up very high and tiny you‚Äôd need good cameras to capture them. If not for that starting at 8.00a.m would be fine where again you will hear bird tweets but hardly seen. Luckily I saw a few endemic birds although I started at 8 o‚Äôclock. There are various types of treks that you can take according to your wish. Treks for around 3 hrs, 5hrs and even longer ones with around 19km which takes almost a day (8a.m.-5p.m) There are 4 entrances to the forest from  different towns. I accessed through Mediripitiya, Deniyaya. The guides doesn‚Äôt necessarily have to be pre booked as they can be called near to the entrance. There is no particular guide fee but it‚Äôs better to tip them with a little more money. The vehicles can‚Äôt go up to the entrance, so you will have to take tuk tuks and the guides can be helpful in here. (Might cost around 250LKR for tuks and also walkable as it‚Äôs around a 1.5km) About the clothing; It‚Äôs up to you to wear either shorts or long pants but it‚Äôs said it‚Äôs better with short because any leaches or insects can be spotted easily. Good trekking or walking shoes are recommended as it would be better for walking while it‚Äôs slippery as well. Better to take some snacks and food along with you where you can sit and enjoy them during the trek and also enough water. So here I come to say what to actually expect. Starting with the entrance the ticket is a very small amount for both locals and foreigners which I assume is toooo low. You can see various types of endemic species and plants, birds, lizards, snails, snakes, butterflies, millipedes and little types of insects. There are 3 elephants and  all the kinds of leopards but are not seen as they do not come close to where the trek is done. The waterfalls are magnificent you can go up in there and enjoy a free fish therapy and also dip yourself in fresh water which is highly recommended. The walking path is where the people of other closer villages pass by so motor bikes are also crossed. The high trees and trekking paths are just too gorgeous to explain. You will feel the inner peace when you walk and feel the nature for sure. Leaches: The most concern of all. It‚Äôs not very harmful at the first place but you can hire leach socks (ask about it at the entrance)but as our guide said a packet of salt will do good enough. That is to apply the table salt on your shoes. I was very lucky to find no leach in my shoes or legs but it is mainly because it didn‚Äôt rain much on the previous days but if it rained there will be more leaches. If you‚Äôre too concerned apply some insect repellents as well. PS: Everyone can‚Äôt expect the same types of insects or snakes to be seen as it differ with the climate and other various factors. I would highly recommend this place if you are truly a nature lover.

The next morning Chaminda picked us up at our hotel; he had already stored the packed breakfasts and lunches in his backpack and off we went. He immediately showed to have a keen eye for all kinds of creatures, large and small, and knew their names well (as a biologist, I was very keen on that aspect of his guidance). Sinharaja rainforest is one of the few remaining rainforests in Sri Lanka. It's a world Heritage site. The forest is shared by the districts of Ratnapura, Galle and Matara. There are 3 official entrances, namely Veddagala (Kudawa),  Morning side and Pitadeniya (Mederipitiya).  The most popular of these is Kudawa that can be reached via Ratnapura - Nivitigala - Kalawana or Matugama (Dodangoda exit of Southern highway) - Agalawatte - Kalawana.  Alternatively, it can be reached via Horana -  Anguruwathota Kukuleganga - Kalawana. If you are coming from Udawalawa take Kahawatte - Nivitigala - Kalawana route. If you are coming down from the central Hills turn left at Thiruwanaketiya close to Ratnapura. The usual trek inside the jungle from the entrance to the research center is about 10km return. Almost anybody should be able to take this relatively easy trail. There are several other trails such as Mulawella, Sinhagala etc. Those are all longer and more difficult. Most bird and animal sightings are on the first trail. It rains to some part of this forest almost daily. Take caps/hats as a minimum precaution. You may even take an umbrella in the rainy season. Leeches are omnipresent. In my opinion sports shoes and denims are the best protection. You got to tuck the denim inside the socks. Despite all the precautions keep an eye on the leeches all the time and all the way. An experienced guide is an asset. He will show you endemic plant and animal species as you walk along. You can't take Polythene inside. Don't venture inside the jungle for fear of snake bites. Leopard also might post a threat. However, so far there have not been Leopard attacks. The two remaining elephants (July 2018)are always angry.  But their habitat is mainly in Rakwana region. When they roam inside the jungle for about 2 months every year in the Kudawa area the guides will not allow visitors to walk all the way in the trails. The forest is home to many beautiful species of endemic birds, butterflies, lizards etc. Blue Magpie and Trogon are two of the most beautiful birds. If you are lucky you might get a chance to see Frog Mouth - an elusive endemic nocturnal bird. They are usually found in male/female pairs perched at eye level inside the jungle during day time. The male and the female are quite different from each other - female being brownish and the male blackish /grayish. You are likely to see many snakes such as Green Pit Vipers, tree snakes etc. Keep your distance from vipers (and Cobra if you see one). Kangaroo lizard is a common site the male of the species being more colourful. Both the National bird of Sri Lanka, Sri Lanka Jungle Fowl and the National butterfly of Sri Lanka, Bird Wing can be found here. The bird is more heard than seen. The Butterfly is seen commonly in certain seasons. What Sinharaja has to offer you is immense. You should spend as much time as possible inside the forest to reap the fruits of visiting this heavenly place on earth.

Sinharaja Rain Forest is known to be the last viable remnant of Sri Lanka‚Äôs tropical lowland rainforests. It spans across an area of 18,900 acres and located within Sabaragamuwa and Southern provinces of the south-west lowland wet zone of Sri Lanka. Sinharaja is also home to over 50% of Sri Lanka‚Äôs endemic species of mammals and butterflies, as well as many kinds of insects, reptiles and rare amphibians.

Sri Lanka's tropical rain forest the Sinharaja is a UNESCO World Natural Heritage Site. The Sinharaja forest, which is situated 30 km from Galle, covers an area of 8900 hectares, and is in fact one of the few virgin forests left in the world. The forest covers a series of mountains and ridges rising abruptly from 90m to 1170m above mean sea level. The Sinharaja forest includes streams, springs, rivers, waterfalls, and is home to leopards, deer, monkeys, butterflies and a variety of trees, shrubs and medicinal herbs are also found within the forest. The Sinharaja forest is unique because it is the only location in Sri Lanka where the altitude changes within one kilometer in an area measuring 01 km from east to west. This factor has contributed to the amazing variety of species of fauna and flora. The largest mammal inhabiting the Sinharaja forest is the Leopard, which is very rarely spotted, also very rarely spotted are the rusty spotted and wild fishing cats. Sambhur, Deer, Wild Boar and Langur Monkeys are much more commonly seen at the Sinharaja forest with 20 species of birds and 45 species of reptiles.

Fabulous forest reserve for bird lovers and nature lovers in general. This forest has been rescued from and attempted mass logging in late 1970's, when a dedicated group of scientist  mounted a scientifically informed campaign.  Since then it has been designated as a Man And Biosphere reserve as well as a world nature heritage site. Today it is the largest intact tract of lowland rainforest in Sri Lanka, which is home to numerous endemic tree, bird and other species. It is considered to be a significant hot spot of global biodiversity and a keystone in evolution. The majestic towering trees, many clear and pure brooks, hundreds of bird species, and the winding paths within this forest are simply impressive.  Guided hikes are included in the modest entrance fee. These guides are employees of the forest dept, and appear to be very well informed. This forest reserve is easily accessible by main roads (last few km on a 4-wheel drive vehicle or on foot). Several options to stay at the boundary of the forest or one option within the border (Martin's Lodge).

This is a wonderful place to experience nature. It is home to a myriad of wonderful birds, plants and animals - but be prepared that you will see just a small amount of what is here. Our guide was very knowledgeable, finding Sri Lanka Frogmouth for us when the rain had begun and all the birds had taken cover, but the visit is a walk out to the research centre then back along the same route - limiting the amount of ground that you cover, unless you take the more challenging path up to the cave.. In November it is usual for the rain to come from late morning for a few hours, and expect it to be heavy, so my advice would be to go first thing in the morning, before the rain so that there are more birds, animals and insects in view. The best place to see birds is in the clearings - there aren't so many of these so take your time when you find one and wait a while at these places hoping for a flock to pass through. It is advisable to take an umbrella. There are also leeches. To limit how much these little nasties get on to you tuck top/shirt into trousers, trouser bottoms into socks, then use leech socks if available - although I and my husband were using waterproof sealskinz socks and these were actually more effect than the leech socks that our guide used. Take alcohol wipes, in case any manage to attach. They tend to march on to potential hosts from the ground so keep laces short, tuck into tongue of boots/shoes if possible. Keep checking clothing for leeches - amazing how fast they move - and they show up more on light coloured clothes.

There seems to be a general myth that detergent and soapy water will get rid of leeches and this old timer is here to tell you that it DOES NOT. As well, the leeches here are faster than in China, Vietnam, Thailand and Australia - faster even that Kitulgala, Sri Lanka! Make sure you bring a cigarette (easiest) or take several handfuls of salt as a teaspoons will not do the trick once a leech has latched on. This was my second only guided trip in 45 years of travel (first being enforced years back in PR China) and though I can manage snakes,poisonous spiders and rats, I am not so great with leeches. Out of consideration for the guide, I kept my eyes on the treetops until we reached a tiny store where someone had a "beedie". Then another helpful individual informed us that leeches often hbernate in large balls high in the trees and drop onto warm blooded creatures passing by underneath. I have since asked several other experienced walkers in Sri Lanka to be told that this is true. Don't be put off; just be prepared. Another tip, if you are taken to the Buddhist retreat be prepared for the Austrian monk to insult you if you are (a) Christian (b) Australian or (c) polite. He does, however have a recipe for a kind of herbal infusion which is effective against high blood sugar. So taken with caution, this can be an interesting experience - as you watch those leeches gallop towards your shoe fastenings just light up a cigarette - and maybe wear a hat!!

Sinharaja Forest reserve is a rain forest located in the south-west of Sri Lanka. Sinharaja is a dense forest and contains an amazing variety of flora and fauna. This is a must-go destination for avid birders. One can sight most of the endemic birds of Sri Lanka in Sinharaja. Red-faced Malkoha, Sri Lanka Scimitar Babbler, Scaly Thrush, Green-billed Coucal, Ashy-headed LaughingThrush, Malabar Trogon.. were some of the gems that I sighted here. The most amazing sight was the mixed flocks unique to Sinharaja. You will find groups containing Malkoha, Trogons, Coucals, Starlings moving within the forest as a single flock. The forest canopy is very dense and may not provide the best photo opportunities. But Sinharaja should not be missed at any cost, for the variety of birds on display.

If you love trees, water falls, absolute quiescence and hiking, this is most definitely a must visit when in Sri Lanka. We entered through the district known as 'Ratnapura' which was a 2.5 hours drive by car from Colombo. It is vital to take the highway from Colombo or face traffic which could lengthen the journey to anywhere between 4 to 6  hours. Furthermore, it is extremely important to bring along a pair of 'leech socks' in order to hike the forest with ease. These socks are sold at the souvenir shop at the entrance. Loved every moment in the forest. Such a feeling to breathe in that fresh unpolluted air inside the forest with only the sounds of water falls, birds and the occasional monkeys resonating around the surrounding. The guides are extremely educated on the surrounding and its inhabitants. We came across monkeys, varied types of butterflies, birds, fishes and lizards most of which were endemic to the beautiful island of Sri Lanka. Further down we found a beautiful little zen like area where the water flows gently from the main water fall that is in the area. We spent more than an hour there just sitting and gazing at the flowing water and listening to the beautiful sounds of the forest.

(1) Entrance from north side of forest is accessed through small roads and some stoney tracks - fine for vehicles etc but not a main road by any stretch of imagination - not many signs to it until you get much closer. (2) Car park right by the tourist entrance - very basic facilities - toilets are just a hole in the ground covered with a loo lid. (3) Seems to be very random if they open their "cafe" which is just a basic coffee tea facility (when we visited midday it was "closed" and no reason given) (4) Guide takes you up - they really need to get this better - our guide spoke virtually no english except single words "spider" "snake" etc - if they can't speak the language a guide book in a different language saying what you see would be really beneficial to take with them.  (seems we just sadly got the wrong guide as other reviews say many are excellent) (5) Admission fee reasonable no objection to paying. (6) Guide didn't warn us about leeches.   The tourist "centre" if you can call it that sells leechproof socks.  Buy them and put them on.  We discovered that they don't just live in water and will drop from trees or leaves onto to the ground or you if they sense a chance at a blood meal - so put full covering on legs and top.   If you do get bitten it is harmless just a nibble pain and then you will bleed for a while but stops - you will not die :) (7) We saw snakes, reptiles, monkeys, spiders, all sorts so very worthwhile. (8) Suggestion bring tea, coffee, drinks, snacks etc as could find there is nothing at the tourist centre on arrival or after.   Busy time is mornings when tour buses arrive lunchtime less so.  Best time to see birds are morning trips but plenty of other stuff on view other times!

Bordered by 4 districts, a world heritage site. About ten months of rain per year with average temperatures around the 20 to 25 C. Home to a number of birds that are endemic to this forest. Also said to be home to bigger mammals such as elephants, leopards and deer though I have not seen them with me eyes probably because the forest cover is so thick. Venomous snakes are said to be few in number with many species of reptiles present in the area. The Head priest of the Buddhist Temple in the area is a very good source of information about the forest and the significance (such as medicinal values) of rare species of plants found there. Do try a plain tea with Kithul Jaggery from the area. Carry your own snacks and drinks / water as there are no shops in the middle of the forest that can be a good half day trek up and down hills. Taking a light rain coat and protection for your camera from the rain would be a good idea.  My actual visit was before stated time. Most of the information above was gathered by watching a TV programme about Sinharaja and some by actual visit.

In hindsight the 6h Tour might have been the nicer, if more "touristy" option. And it very much depends on your guide, which we couldn't really influence :-(

Shortly, we'll be uploading the photo of our guide. We can't remember his name but he was incredible. He was so sweet, friendly, helpful, knowledgeable and willing to show us the best of Sinharaja! We learnt so much along our way but I won't put too much on here as it's great to learn as you go. He asked us if we wanted to go on a long walk uphill. We was exhausted when we finished but we got to the highest point of Sinharaja on top of a mountain and the view at the top was spectatular. A once in a lifetime sort of view. Besides this, we saw so many animals, plants and insects. Our guide was very funny too as we had a little giggle as we struggled up the mountain and he hopped up as if it was the easiest thing ever! He was a little shocked to learn we didn't walk hills most of the time! It was something so normal to him. He showed us how to drink the river walk which we did (reluctantly) but don't be scared as the water was so fresh and cold and I couldn't quite believe it wasn't half frozen bottled water as it tasted so nice. This was one of our best days in Sri Lanka and I think this was definitely because of the staff as well as the beautiful things Sinharaja has to offer. You have to visit this place! You'll miss out if you don't go!

3 lovely waterfalls with higher bio-divercity.. roads are not that great.. go in the morning as their are elephants around the access road in the evening.. from tje car park have to walk 3km since the roads are very tiny and accessible only from bikes.. so be prepared. carry tourches if you happen to go in the evening.. Leave nothing bit the foot prints..

A couple of previous reviewers have referred to this as 'rainforest lite' and that would probably be a fair description. However, that is not necessarily a bad thing. The paths are well made and mostly flat and make for relatively easy walking. We booked an official park guide to take us round and he was very good at spotting many small reptiles, birds and insects. Don't expect to spot much in the way of furry animals here though other than a few monkeys. We were lucky enough to see a couple of large groups of purple faced monkeys at quite close quarters which was fantastic. We had hoped to see the waterfalls we had read about but it seems we had entered the park at the wrong entrance - due to the fact that our driver had never been here before and did not know to take us to the Galle entrance. Doesn't compare with some more unspoilt tropical rainforests but enjoy it for what it is - an enjoyable 3 hour walk in some beautiful scenery.

This forest is a wonderful place, a beautiful tropical forest, quite some interesting animals and a beautiful waterfall. However, it was very disappointing that there is no fixed prices, that there is motorbikes driving in the forest all the time (in order to reach a village nearby), there is dogs that the guides do not try to keep out and our guide was smoking the whole tour. It doesn't seem like they take very good care of this incredible place, and that is very sad.

i have been more then 15 time to singharaja. Kudawa,weddagala,Kalawana entrance and Galle side entrance. if you want to get real rain forest experience i recommended only Kudawa, kalawana entrance. reason is this entrance available facilitates more than other entrance. in this entrance available good knowledgeable site tour guide,they have many experience about the forest,birds,snakes,and all around the forest.they help to for everything.i recommended only way to Kudawa,kalawana way.

Interesting 2-4h walk, particularly if you have not walked in a tropical forest before. The paths are made partially of cement slabs and rocks, and are well market throughout. Some parts are not suitable for disabled people, but good for children. The sight of elephant tracks (and dung) make it exciting for the children. If you use a guide, don‚Äôt expect great naturalist or linguistic skills, but they have a trained eye for interesting plants and invertebrates. You will struggle, however, to find a single leech or mosquito. This is the rainy season, and the most experienced guides walked in shorts and flip-flops, which is telling. Swimming is safe. The paths inside the park are crossed daily by hundreds of local people, often in motorbikes, and certainly not accompanied by guides. In addition to all the visitors, this makes it a crowded park, particularly in the paths close to the entrances. The entrance ticket to the park costs now about Rs 600. One should not have to pay more than that for a guide (per adult). This is already a bit higher than the Sri Lankan tourists in small groups pay for a guide. The best strategy is to sit in a restaurant by the park entrance, enjoy a beer or an excellent curry, and negotiate the price with one of the local villagers that are, so-called, certified guides. The first offer you get may be 5 times higher than the park fee, which is obviously a swindle. Take it easy, prices will come down. But, remember that by 17:30 it starts to get dark. Plan to arrive early.

Some of the trails are pretty rough and rocky, but others are flat and nice. Saw lots of birds and insects and a couple of snakes. Having a good forest guide (you pick one up at the park entrance) was very worthwhile and I tipped ours well. The forest is pretty thick so sometimes it's difficult to see birds and so forth. We spend about 4 hours or so hiking around. Very worthwhile.

It is a small rain forest and you don't get to see a lot of it if you take a three-four hour tour. But all and all it was a nice walk. We spotted some monkeys, giant squirrel, snakes, lizards, scorpion, spiders,... And we had a chance to swim in the river by one of the waterfalls, which was refreshing and fun. It is important to have a good guide, who can spot all the animals and show them. We've had the best guide (but unfortunately I don't remember his name): He is a young guy, official forest guide. He was very into nature, wildlife, and was full of information and had a great eye for spotting animals. He really made our walk perfect.

A little out of the way from most other attractions in Sri Lanka but if you are interested in wildlife its worth the trip.  The hike wasn't as long as I was hoping but we still saw three different vipers, bump nosed lizards, kangaroo lizards, giant squirrel and a few other animals.

We had a very informative guide with a good eye for wildlife for our trip through the reserve.  We saw monkeys, lizards, a giant squirrel, snakes and birds. The hike itself was not terribly difficult and would be okay for kids and adults with an average level of fitness.  It was a 2.5 hour, fairly unpleasant, drive from Galle.  It was worth the trip for us because we enjoyed the wildlife.  If we were going to do it again we may opt to stay closer and be able to arrive early to see more of the wildlife.  We arrived about 9am.  The part opens around 6am. Despite tucking our pants into our socks, my husband did find a leech on his leg after the hike which was super gross.
sinharaja rain forest is the better place for birds lovers. But not only the birds , reptiles ,butterflise, fresh water fishes all so can see. espacially for many endemic birds can see.

Yes there is a well trodden path and yes, you do get locals using this route as a cut through on motorbikes as other reviewers have said. So it's not perhaps a fully authentic rainforest experience for serious trekkers and/or nature lovers. But for most people, especially in the heat, a couple of hours "trekking" is enough and there is lots to see. You do need to take a guide, so your experience will partly depend on their skill/ English in explaining to you, but we saw quite a lot and the kids (13 and 11) really enjoyed. Our driver who is also a ranger didn't come with on this trip which was a shame as I think we would have got more out of the trip if he had. The path involves climbing over rocks/ tree roots so whilst some did it barefoot/ in flip flops, trainers etc are probably best. the halfway point is at a beautiful waterfall and the locals were swimming there so take swimsuits etc if you want to do the same. It's a pity the walk back is exactly the same - apparently there is a slightly longer walk that would have gone deeper in the rainforest and if we'd known, we'd have made sure we had time (we did an afternoon walk so needed to be out before sunset). The bridge across the water was good fun (wobbly but great photo opportunity) and the waterfall was a lovely place to sit and rest and soak up the sights and sounds.

We went to the Sinharaja Rain Forest, entering on the Deniyaya side.  You pick up a guide and a ticket near the entrance (Tickets are approx LKR 600 per person and you give the guide a tip at the end (approx LKR 1500-2000 seems the norm).  Do not get a package from your hotel as you will get ripped off. Yout then go for a walk for a few hours in the forest up to a waterfall, being shown the local flora and fauna by the guide.  Generally there are lots of insects, a couple of snakes, some small mammals, a few birds, and lots and lots of trees. Everyone seems to take the same route and see the same things.  It's not very strenuous - really a 'rain forest lite' experience, but a good taster of what the rain forest is like. Overall, a very nice way to spend half a day.

We had a guide to lead us, he is very experienced, and we saw two type of snakes, 3 types of lizards and more, nice to walk in the forest, a lot of local school students also enjoy the forest that day.

I wanted to photograph reptiles and insects with my macrophoto lens. Thanks to Hassun the guide from Mideripitiya I saw a Greenpit viper, Sri-Lanka kangaroo lizard and several kinds of beautifully colored lizards, spider wasp and more. After a four hour walk I returned with phantastic photos and a memorable rainforest experience.

You have to travel from Galle 80Km away from sea side and meet Deniyaya. Its  cold climate with Urban area which has nice looking area. If you need to travel to Sinharaja you have to go another 20Km to reach there. Its heritage of srilanka and its has Trees,Animals,Waterfalls,Bee Honeys,Kuthul Honey. Very Nice

We travelled to Sinharaja from Tangalle today...  About 2.5 hours so a reasonable trek to the southern entrance outside Deniyaya. The road ends and you are in a very small village where tuk Tuks are there to take you up the bumpy trail to the Forest office where you buy your tickets (560 lkr each).  Tuk tuk was 250 lkr each way.  we were told in the village that the guides all had to be hired in village, our driver seemed sceptical but nonetheless we went ahead with a "guide".   On reflection I don't believe he was a true "guide" as on the trail we noted other guys with official polo shirts, rucksacks, and binoculars...  Our guide was in tracksuit bottoms with a bottle of 7-up.  My fears were confirmed when his initial quote for the 3 hour walk was 4600 lkr, rather more than the 2000 lkr I was told  to expect.  Some haggling later we were at 2500 for 3 hour trek and set to go.   It started off promisingly ...  Tiny luminous green snake, massive millipede, rhino fly all spotted in a few minutes, then a couple of lizards...   But then things literally dried up and we diverted off to the track to the conservation centre for 10 minutes sit down, Nothing there apart from some faded pictures...  Then after a total of a 1 hour slow walking on a very, very well trodden path (avoiding locals on motorbikes as mentioned in other posts regarding this southern entrance) we arrived at a picturesque, but hardly awe inspiring waterfall, where we sat for another 10mins before a brisk walk back down the same path and back to base.. Avoiding those motorbikes again.  Luckily we saw a serpent eagle high up in a tree on the way back or else it would have been a zero spot rapid trek back - total time start to finish 2 hours 10 and we only made it to first waterfall.  Should have asked for trip to 2nd waterfall instead of stating a time.  Although, apparently, you do have to wade to get to the second. So in summary I would have to agree with earlier posts about this southern entrance and say that it is spoiled by the motorbikes which must scare off the timid wildlife and please make sure you get a proper "guide" with binoculars and who has time and inclination to be able to look for and find whatever wildlife does stay close to the main route. To be fair and for reference we hit the trail at 9am and that may well have been too late to see the bulk of the wildlife...  So my advice would be go to the north entrance, go early, get an official guide with binoculars and spend more than 3 hours :-)

If you like walking around in natural forests with multiple activities this is the place. It's not easily accessible as it's at least a couple hours drive from any civilized accommodation but once you get there it's a great activity for a full day. You have to get a tuk tuk from a nearby village to get to the park. There are multiple waterfalls and interesting trees around. The water is pretty nice if you like to swim in rivers or lakes. The trek isn't very demanding and almost anyone can handle it. Since it's a rainforest there's a lot of humidity and camping in the forest could be quite a wet activity. There are various snakes and spiders around so if you are specifically interested in them this is a nice place to find many. We only spent day in the park so we had to choose among multiple alternatives to limit the trek but it's well worth the trip.

We visited via the southern entrance. The main track follows the river that marks the southern boundary of the park. The track is much-used by local villagers, including an occasional man on a motorbike -  not my idea of a nature reserve. The only furred animals that we saw were dogs. Having said that, the forest is beautiful and swimming to a waterfall at the end of the trek was a wonderful experience. Leeches are numerous, but not problematic if one keeps moving. We enjoyed our day out, but it would be better if the park were properly protected.

Sinharaja is one of International Man and Biosphere Reserve by UNESCO. There are two main entrance manages by Forest Department. Deniyaya(from Galle) , Kalawana ( Via Rathnapura-Veddagala). One of the best place to bird watching in Sri Lanka. Ticket counter open around 6.30am. Go early morning(as much as you can) or evening (3pm to 6pm). There are trackers you can hire for your journey through forest. Around deniyaya area you can see lots of Waterfalls. The Sinhagala track is the longest and hardest track.

It is a giant rainforest so there is things to see for days. We only spent maybe 3 hours in there with our guide who had so much knowledge and was able to spot all sorts of animals for us. Prepare to walk lots and drink lots of water because it's hot in there. Just beware there is no toilet facilities.

this is definitely off the beaten track and not very popular yet with tourists. When we arrived there was a big party of school children as this is where all Sri Lankan children go for their school trips, we thought we wouldn't see much because they were a bit noisy. How wrong we were this is Virgin rain forest and we saw some amazing giant snails, large spiders and butterflies bigger than my hand, we saw loads it was simply stunning. We will definitely go again.
This is a must see when in the south of Sri Lanka. The wetland forest is filled with wildlife and is a magnificent experience!
there can be leeches....!! so be prepared to take them away.......! might need a rain coat if it rains....you will be able to see few waterfalls as well.
We travel from Galle to the forest area by car.stayed at Deniyaya.Stayed 5 hours in the jungle wet and greenly .Walk about 8 Km.

It's a world heritage forest in Sri Lanka with lot of species and endemic species. Lot of interesting sight seeings interesting places. It's a wonderful place to visit. Lot of medicinal plants, unseen flowers, unseen reptiles and amphibians to see. But, be careful of leaches...

Let's be clear. This is a walk along a well trodden path through the rainforest. Surprisingly It is also much used by locals often on motorbikes to cross the forest. You will also meet many other groups of tourists on the trail.It is a miracle that one sees any wildlife at all, perhaps they are used to it. Pali seems to be the only guide that shows any genuine enthusiasm for the wildlife.The rest just go through the motions. The only animal they are interested in is the cash cow. The whole thing is just another money spinner. A lot of guides will get you to rush back on the return path in order to fit in a visit to the tea plantation and buy way overpriced tea. Another money spinner. My advice is make use of a full day in the forest and visit the plantation on another day if you are interested. Once you accept all that , it is still a nice walk and you will be contributing to the local economy. Just don't have too high expectations.

We are hiking enthusiasts and found the difficult, less traveled, off the beaten path trails amazing. The waterfalls were an absolute delight after a difficult hike and the hidden trails were pristine. The well traveled ones are good and easy going, but can get crowded very fast. One word of caution, pay at the official entrance and hire a guide there. Pre-booking through hotels or guest houses result in dodgy hidden fees - still cheap, but as a local, I wouldn't want inappropriate tourism practices to succeed.

Wonderful trek along the neatly paved trail. Rocky trail but made it all the more interesting. Guides are available and knowledgeable. Saw some rare bird species - serendib scops owl, wood pigeon, blue naped monarch and vine snake. Beautiful opportunity for photography.
Beautiful trails and nature walks. Swimming in the river after a hike is the best. You will need a guide as it is not permitted to go by yourself.

Sinharaja forest is the largest rain forest of Sri Lanka and there are three entrances for that. Rathnapura-Kudawa entrance is the famous out of it. When you enter Sinharaja rain forest through Kudawa entrance, you can do Sinhagala and Mulawella trails. This is the famous area for bird watching as well. Sinhagala trail gets about a whole day to complete. At the end you will reach top of Sinhagala and can have nice panoramic view. But you have to start it early morning before 7am. Best months for visit is from December to May as rain comes in other parts of the year. Better prepared with leech protection methods as well. No beautiful waterfalls  come across through this entrance like other two entrances.

We went there about day. There are very scenic hiking tracks, small waterfalls, in which pools you can take a cool refreshing bath. We saw there many types of lizards, some snakes and butterflyes. Beware of leechers!

Note that there are 2 entrances to the forest area, North and South. For birdwatching the Northern part seems where most people head, but it's probably more difficult getting there than the Southern entrance. This post is about the Northern side only. Choices of accommodation is limited and expensive in comparison to the rest of Sri Lanka. You really need 2 days minimum or 1 overnight stay close by to make it worthwhile, a day-trip is not realistic in my opinion. Taking a guide is compulsory Rs1000 + Rs 650 pp entrance fee. The road up to the Ticket Office and parking area is tarmac & accessible to any vehicle. At the Ticket Office you pay your fees, sign the foreign visitors book and get your guide. The guides are all very experienced and know their stuff so don't worry. You then have to walk to the actual park entrance about 2 km uphill along the Park Road (pedestrian only) that goes through forest. (Some people get ferried uphill by arranged jeep, but this is back on a completely different track - Martin's Rd - and it's not very pleasant + expensive.) See the map on my photo uploads - the one in Google maps is completely incorrect. Once you reach the Entrance Office, they will sign you in and let you through. The main trail is very broad and fairly flat with resting shelters and toilets along the way. You are not "trekking" through the jungle. It's more like an easy stroll really. In March the forest was very dry with not a single leech in sight either. The main trail from the Entrance Office leads to a Rangers Station a few kilometres further on but there are other smaller side trails too. I was very content walking the main trail at a slow pace to spot as many things as we could, finding a feeding flock of birds is brilliant and you can easily spend an hour rooted in one spot trying to pick out different species. I found the fact that none of the guides use binoculars amazing! Note for birders - If you have spare time walk the access road between the Ticket Office and Kudawa Bridge below. Some good birding to be had here as well as in the actual Ticket Office grounds.

We trekked the Sinharaja Rainforest on 2 separate mornings.  The experience was nothing short of exceptional.  We saw birds, lizards, snakes, monkeys, giant squirrels, scorpions, bats, crabs, fish, crayfish, butterflies and well as plenty of flora.  We also got to swim in a rainforest waterfall. The guides are a wealth of knowledge and can spot the impossible. Our trip to Sri Lanka also included jeep safaris around the more famous nature reserves, but they paled in comparison to the on foot rainforest trekking. Advice: Wear decent walking shoes; be aware that there are leeches (easily dealt with and not dangerous); take plenty of water; take your swimming gear :)

We had a great day out in the forest. This forest itself has a lot to offer in the way of wildlife and plants and also the river and waterfalls. But in order to really appreciate it you need a good guide.  We took Dilshan on Sinharaja Rest in Deniyaya who was terrific and really made our day.  Also the  guide from the Forestry Dept, Anura I think his name was, was a good spotter and went out of his way to find us interesting creatures and plants.

A must visit place for adventurists and nature lovers, You'll be able to see over 100 types fauna & flora, though we were unfortunate to spot any big mammals as most of them are deep in the jungle, however we spotted many birds,insects and snakes. one must make sure to be fully geared with water,clothing to keep the LEACHES away along with a cake of soap another method of getting rid of leaches, snacks, good shoes etc. According to our guide the forest reserve is approx 11,000 acres so it advisable to stick with your guide,unless you know the place at the back of your head.
Really far from the city. If you plan to visit start early by 6:00 a.m and only if you are a true nature loved.

We took main, north-west entrance (nearest village- Pothupitiya). We paid 2200LKR for 2 entry tickets and a guide. We trailed to big tree, which was about. 6.5km one way. The trail was very easy,  more like a walk in the park than actual trekking. You can do it in flip-flops. It took us 2.5 hours to return with one stop on the way. We were lucky with a guide,  a guy with university degree in biology and eagle eye.  He found for us few reptiles,  birds and butterflies.  All endemic species to Sri Lanka. We also saw 2 species of monkey. The guy give us names of all the species in Sinharaja,  English and Latin and also shared some interesting facts about Park and Sri Lanka in general. In overall nice experience of local nature.
Great primal forest . Try to book a trek with Pali from Sinharaja Rest guest house in Deniyaya , he is the best .

We visited the forest with all our family and it was a real adventure. When we did enter the forest it started to rain havily and stopped only after two hours. NOt sure, but can be rather regular rain as we did visit it in the afternoon time. Anyway we did manage to get to the waterfall and it was very nice, however we did not bath there as were already completely wet. Problem was that before our trip we asked everybody about leaches and were assured this is the dry season and there are not there. However on the way back from the waterfall it was realy fight with leaches - they stick to your shoes and climb up, so if you have just shorts you have to count you experience them as we did. They are not dangerous and will drop off after some 5 minutes when they are full of your blood, but it is scary and when we got the first onece we could not help up not to stop and check every minute of our walk. Probably also because of the rain we saw limited number of animals, most impressive was to hear very loud screems of monekey, but we could not see them, also spiders 10 cm big and really huge trees.

Sinharaja is a lovely place and we saw some exciting and uncommon birds. Sinharaja is for those who are serious about bird-watching are prepared to do a fair bit of walking and are equipped with good binoculars and leech socks. Our naturalist guide was very knowledgeable and was able to spot and identify birds quickly. I would recommend an early arrival around 7am because it seems they run out of guides and Jeeps. Having obtained our tickets and found the naturalist guide, we had to wait 20 minutes or so for a Jeep (even at 7am). This took us up the hill on an extremely rough road (15 minutes) and left us with the naturalist guide to walk through the reserve. It would be possible to walk up the hill but it would take a long time to get to the heart of the reserve. After some 2 - 3 hours, the naturalist guide suggested we go to the ‚Äúvillage area‚Äù in a Jeep where he reckoned we could see a number of birds not previously seen. So we waited 20 minutes or so for another Jeep and started back down the hill. Halfway down, we met the original Jeep coming up and changed vehicle. At the bottom we met our chauffeur/guide who had taken us to the reserve and he explained that if we took the Jeep to the ‚Äúvillage‚Äù, which it appeared was outside the park area, it would cost extra (some 3500 rupees). He explained that what we had paid for was one Jeep trip up the hill and down again. We declined the Jeep but the chauffeur/guide took us in the car as far as he could and we agreed to walk the rest with the naturalist guide. We never really reconciled whether the naturalist guide was simply trying to get us the best bird-watching experience and see the most interesting birds, or whether he was trying to rip us off by luring us into extra charges. I don‚Äôt know what our agent in Sri Lanka expected and had paid for the package that we had but, from the contract we were sent, I had expected that the Jeep and naturalist guide would be at our disposal for the day. However, we saw lots of exciting and uncommon birds, had a lovely day in the rain forest and came away happy and content. What more could we ask?

We stayed in Talpe and we had to start from the hotel at 5:00 AM. We had a breakfast in Sri Lankan style by the entrance of the rainforest. It was interesting, we did not know what we exactly eat. :)) After the breakfast we walked into the rainforest with our guide. He was friendly and had eagle eyes, he discovered a lot of tiny insects. We saw a snake, snails, lizards, monkeys, but we did not see any birds. I wanted to take photographs about some beautiful birds, but they did not come. Anyway, the forest and the waterfall are beautiful, and the tour/walking was really easy.

Our group had an amazing trek with Mr. Pali (of Sinharaja Rest House). We saw birds such as the Grey Hornbill, Imperial Green Pigeon, blue Monarch bird, and Paradise Flycatcher. We observed a number of reptiles at close range, including the kangaroo lizard, pit viper, Blossom's krait, and many more. In the middle of our trek, we took a short break to swim at the waterfall. As it was a Sunday, it was a bit more crowded than usual and yes, there were terrestrial leaches so be prepared with proper footwear and precautions. Leaches and crowds aside, the biodiversity is incredible, and we had a great time!
This place is 3 hours from Colombo and quite a gem. Very peaceful and great for hikers. Lots of pictures to take and just take a week here..

Arrived here around 5.30-6.00am in the morning in hoping to spot some birds here. Our guide were experienced, attentive and observant enough to discover all the birds and animals in the area. We saw more than 10 different species such as as blue magpies, bukbulk bird, long tail squirrels, grey face monkey, blue face monkey, kangaroo lizard, green vine snake, green viper and so o.n ! To us, the hike was too easy and we should have gone for a 25km hike to the northwest exit. I strongly suggest experienced hikers to do that! But to sum up we enjoyed the experience and the swim in the waterfall!

I didn't read all those bad reviews about this entrance and it was a HUGE mistake, it was complete rip off. 1000LKR/per person for a 3h guide, 560LKR/per person entrance fee, overpriced 'mandatory' lunch/breakfast, 1000LKR for 1km tuk ride to start of the tour. Zero animals. They even tried to squeeze more money from us on leaving because trip took a little more over 3h. Do not go there!!

The forest is really great. I would recommend a full day tour. We took a short tour (3-4 hours). You just walk along the forest and see few animals. To see more and real jungle you need to take a day tour.

Easy walking paths through the jungle, you'll see a few birds, insects, the usual monkeys and the occasional snake if you're lucky. It's ok but we've seen much more exciting jungle trecks in South-East Asia and South America.

It is true that the journey up is long and slow, the views on the way are spectacular , but the journey is worth it to stay in a rainforest and enjoy guided walks through the jungle seeing birds and small creatures, flowers and trees is a terrific experience. Rainforests are always difficult for animal spotting, bit the Black purple faced monkeys make their presence felt and some of the rare birds we saw were spectacular. Don't forget the little joys, butterflies, dragonflies, frogs and tiny lizards, waterfalls and rocky rivers and giant trees. Our guide was excellent and knowledgeable and we had a terrific couple of days there.

It is always nice and interesting to walk in a rainforest. My husband and I did a 3 hours' walk with a guide. We were perhaps unlucky as we did not see much as far as animals are concerned. A few monkeys and a viper. We did not see many flowers. A bit disappointing.

Sinharaja Forest Reserve is simply one of the best places in Sri Lanka to imerse yourself in nature. Dont take much notice of reviews from tourists complaining about the journey up. It is a bit bumpy but the 4x4's cope with this very well and it only takes about 45 minutes from the accommodations near the entrance gate at the bottom of this mountain. Full of endemic wildlife which is not all easy to see, if you love nature and are not just a moaning general tourist, then this is paradise.

X4 of us endured a gruelling 2 1/2 hour journey to cover 52km from Koggala to Sinharaja over the bendiest roads ever. If you don't suffer with travel sickness you might after this journey! We started out at 6.30am and arrived for 9. We saw about 12 species of birds and x3 snakes with our guide. Birding was the usual difficult dense forest type. I would suggest if you are going to bother going here you need to do an overnight stay local to the forest for a dusk then dawn visit. Otherwise go to Udawalawe where the birding is easier.
Sinharaja forest is the only primary climax rain forest left in Sri Lanka, with its unique and varied plant and wild life it never seizes to amaze me.

We spent a couple of nights a Sinharaja Forest Reserve in the middle of a dry spell, so I don't know what it is like when it rains. I really enjoyed our stay here, it's a tourist location but not touristy. The relatively small number of guests gives it a country house hotel feel as we had conversations with a number of other residents. The accommodation is in T shaped metal buildings, they are large enough for two with good showers, bed and settee. They also have a number of UK sockets, we also had an extension lead. Interestingly we were able to sleep with the windows open as there does not seem to be any flying biting creatures at all. Breakfast and dinner were both good, although there is only a choice of two main courses for the 5 course dinner. Our travel agent said they do not serve alcohol which is not true. The WIFI is a little erratic but it did not prevent me from doing everything I wanted to do online. The high spots are the very relaxed walks with the personable and knowledgeable guides. We did 3 in one day the 6.30 am bird watching 3.3 miles along a road, the rainforest walk around 3 hours over reasonably easy ground and the waterfall walk somewhat steeper. On the latter walk one can paddle in the water and let the fish clear any dead skin of your feet. The walks are free and there is nothing to stop you going on the same one twice. There was an evening walk on offer as well. As others have said leech socks are provided I wore them on the second walk but not on the last one when I had shorts and crocs on. The journey to the hotel is 'interesting' as it's pretty steep and narrow, our driver had no problems but others did especially if it was the first time they had done it.

The jungle tour with the provided guide was excellent. You have a choice of  lengths and we chose the two waterfall tour which was a nice compromise between too short and exhausting. Sinharaja World Heritage Reserve, Man and Biosphere (MAB) Reserve the largest remaining undisturbed south western lowland rainforest in Sri Lanka, categorized as a tropical wet evergreen forest. Dense and mysterious Sinharaja is a forest for many activities: photography, leisure and for scientific exploration and is Sri Lankas greatest natural heritage. It spans over the districts of Ratnapura, Galle and Matara.  The Reserve lies in the south-west of the island at 60 21' - 60 26' N. and 800 21' - 800 34' E. It measure 21 kilometers in length, and 7 kilometers in width at its widest point and 3 kilometers at its‚Äô narrowest. Sinharaja is a rain forest of 11,187 hectares. With the contiguous Morapitiya ‚Äì Runakanda, Panagala, Dellawa, Neluketiya, Warathalagoda and Delgoda forest reserves Sinharaja becomes the largest wet zone forest. It is extending across an altitudinal range of 210 to 1180 m.  Sinharaja forests covers receives 3750-5000mm of rain throughout the year. The Plant density inside the forest is 240,000 plants per hectare. Sinharaja forest is highly recognized as a biologically unique ecosystem because of its endemic tree species (More than 60%) and many of them are considered rare. It does not stop from that. It is also home to over 50% of Sri Lanka's endemic species of birds, mammals, butterflies, as well as many kinds of insects, reptiles and rare amphibians. It was declared as an international Man and Biosphere reserve (MAB) and a world heritage site by UNESCO in 1978 and 1988. Sri Lanka is a continental island. Although the island has been connected with the mainland time to time by land bridges since the initial separation, forests have been identified as being ecologically isolated. Western Ghats in India are the closest other moist forests to Sri Lanka. Western Ghats of India and South Western of Sri Lanka comprise of one of the 34 bio diversity hotspots of the world. This shows the exceptionally high level of endemism and diversity. Also the threat it faces. Enter the wilderness. From Northern or Western parts of the country you can reach Sinharaja forest reserve via Ratnapura, Kiriella, Kalawana, Weddala. From the South you can enter Sinharaja Rain Forest from Deniyaya. Coming from Hambantota, Udawalawe you can enter Sinharaja from Rakwana side. The best period to visit the forest is between December and early April or between August and September. Kudawa entrance Colombo to Mathugama or Rathnapura and then to Kalawana and Weddagala at which point you turn off the main road to the forest department camp at Kudawa. Public transport is available up to Weddagala via Mathugama 117km and via Ratnapura 154km. Weddagala to Kudawa 5.6 km public transport facilities are available. Pitadeniya Entrance Colombo to Mathugama and then to Deniyaya via Neluwa travel 10km from Deniyaya to Mederipitiya and then walk 3kmfurther and cross Gin Ganga to reach the camp. The camp is located by the side of Gin Ganga in Dombagoda forest. Morning Side Entrance Colombo to Rakwana via Deniyaya or Rathnapura and proceed through Suriyakanda and turn off the main road through morning side state track to forest department conservation center. Visitors can reach up to Rakwana by public transport and have to walk about 05 km through state track if private transport is not arranged. How the Sinharaja rain forest acquired its name has many stories with different versions. However none has been proved scientifically, but still Falk lore & legends are always interesting and catch our attention. It gives us a mixed feeling of creep, inquisitiveness and past gloriousness. Sinharaja Forest myths are lost in the mists of legend and lore. Its name, literally meaning lion (sinha ) king (raja ).Both the forest and the Sinhalese people derive their names from the Sinhalese word "Sinha" ‚Äì the Lion, and according to legend, sinhalese race is the result of the union between a princess and a mighty lion who lived in the forest. Perhaps it also refers to the people of the legendary 'lion-race' of Sri Lanka, or to the home of a legendary lion of Sri Lanka. Some legends state that in the Sinharaja forest lived a mighty lion that ruled the area brought dread in to the hearts of the villagers. Another says that the ‚ÄúSinharaja Adaviya‚Äù meaning the Sinharaja forest is said to have been the royal territory belonging to the ancient Kings of Sri Lanka. Sinharajas habitat comprises of four main stratums. They are: Canopy, Sub canopy, Under storey and Ground flora. These play a vital role in keeping together the relationship between flora and fauna, its distribution and sustainability. Trees that grow with a height of 30-45m are considered as canopy. They absorb sunlight freely and grow to be giants. Average diameter reaches up to 5m (16feet).  Sub canopy group to block the sunlight from falling below. They grow up to a height of 25-30m and join hands with each other to create a layer like canopy. Under storey consists of trees with heights up to 20-25m and has a horizontal growth pattern. Take usage of the available space. Ground flora has very little opportunity to absorb sun light so they have the survival technique to grow with minimum supply of sunlight. Mostly ferns and shrubs belong to this category. Other than these major categories there are epiphytes that grow on the trunks of trees, climbers which are vines that grow up and around the trees searching for sun light and parasites that grows on trees and nourished by trees. Different types of fungi also grow in abundance. Nature rivulet emerging from the forest of Sinharaja is a common sight. Over the wooded area with crystal clear water draining into various ways is truly breathtaking. Sinharaja forest plays a vital role in maintaining the continuous supply of water. These rivulets found within the forest, feed the rivers like Kalu Ganga and Gin Ganga. The vegetation within the reserve can be categorized into three main types: the lower slopes and valleys (150 - 600 meters), middle slopes (600 - 1000 meters) and the upper slopes and ridges (above 1,000 meters)The lower slopes and valleys have trees like ‚Äúhora, bu hora‚Äù as the dominant canopy trees. On the middle slopes there are trees like Batu Na, Diya Na and Dun. In the upper slopes and ridges, the tree size decreases. Among the large trees of the canopy, columnar tree boles are an abundant sight. These are supported by plank buttress roots, a common characteristic of large rain forest trees. The total vegetation density of the forest has been estimated to be around 240,000 individuals per hectare. Forest gaps occur randomly and are caused by natural phenomena such as the death of large trees or the uprooting by the wind. In these gaps when the light starts to reach the ground, growth rate of saplings and other vegetation increase vigorously and forms impenetrable thickets. Bio Diversity of Sinharaja is unique and among the richest in the world. Many researches have been carried out and are being done up to date. Even today new species of plants and animals are discovered. Sinharaja has typical tropical lowland rain forest or tropical wet evergreen forest bio diversity. In the Sinharaja, floristic studies revealed the presence of many endemic floras. Sinharaja has many trees with high medicinal value. E.g. Venival, Godapara, Keena, Wanaraja, Iru raja etc are used to cure tetanus, joint breaks and sprains, snake bites. Insect trapper (Badura) and wanaraja are plants that can be observed in Sinharaja, famous for the insect trapping mechanism and medicinal qualities. The reserve is famous as a house of Orchids. They are spread throughout the reserve with their graceful beauty adding a touch of elegance to the reserve. The reserve is famous for endemic birds; it is the ideal place for ornithologists and bird watchers to study about feeding flocks. Almost all bird watchers and bird lovers visit Sinharaja to study about these endemic and migrant birds where very little resources are needed. In Sinharaja during an observation of a bird flock, one can observe about 30-50 birds belonging to different species. Capturing the perfect moment of a flock is truly challenging but rewarding too.  These flocks give life to the forest with their noise and movements.  Feeding flocks of Sinharaja are the most studied group in the world. So what is a flock? A flock can be described as two or more species moving in the same direction. A feeding flock means a one with movements associated with feeding. They can sometimes be mixed flocks. E.g. birds with squirrels.The most frequent species in the flocks were the Orange-billed Babbler and the Great Crested Drongo. Some of the rare and attractive endemic bird species in Sinharaja are Sri Lanka Red-Faced Malkoha, Sri Lanka Magpie, Sri Lanka Spur- Fowl, Sri Lanka Ashy-Headed Laughing Thrush, Sri Lankan White Faced Starling, Green Billed Cockle, Serendib Scope Owl. Sinharaja possess the perfect environment for amphibians; nature rivulets, wet soil, humidity, constant rains make it the ideal place for their habitat.  Many species of tree frogs can be found in Sinharaja and other Lowland rain forests of Sri Lanka and most of them are endemic and rare. Some were recently discovered and still there are many researches done on this field. Some of the rare and endemic frog species recorded only in Sinharaja from the world. Among the reptiles Green Garden Lizard, Common Garden Lizard and endemic Kangaroo Lizards are common. With a little luck Hump Nosed Lizard is the largest in the island and one of the most attractive lizards one will observe in Sinharaja. Three lizard species are of most important to Sinharaja. Two are recorded only in the morning side of the reserve and the world; they are, Eartleny Horn Lizard and Karus Horn Lizard. The Rough Horn Lizard is recorded only in Sinharaja and other wet lowland rain forests. Among the snakes The Green Pit Viper is endemic and Hump-nosed Viper, green vine snake are commonly found in this forest. Blossom krait is one of the few rare snakes recorded in lowland rain forests. Natures flying fairies; the butterflies bring Sinharaja vivid beauty that transfers the mysteriousness of the jungle to a decorative fantasy. Ceylon Bird Wing, Sri Lankan Tree Nymph Sri Lankan Blue Oak-leaf and Ceylon Rose are some endemic and rare attractive butterflies. Blue Mormon, Clipper,, Commander, Tale-jay, Common Mormon, Common Rose are some beautiful and large butterflies commonly found in the reserve. Sometimes Ceylon Rose and Oak-leaf may not appear as much as the others. Sambhur, the Mouse deer and barking deer are commonly found within the reserve. Leopards and fishing cat are very seldom sighted, purple - faced Leaf Monkey and giant squirrels also commonly observed. Red slender Loris, little ring civet cat, common farm civet cat, flying squirrel, are some nocturnal mammals. In Sri Lanka, wilderness areas have long been subject to the activities of man, and Sinharaja is no exception. There are many villages scattered around the reserve. Villagers in these areas produce jaggery. Although the palm is not deliberately planted by the villagers, seedlings which come up naturally tended and looked after. Tapping of trees within the forest is controlled by the Forest Department. Another source of income for the villagers is the manufacture of baskets and other woven products made of ‚Äúwewal and bamboo‚Äù. The villagers also exploit other plant products. The fuel used by the villagers for cooking, making jaggery is firewood gathered from the forest. The villagers also collect and sell products from a number of plants like dried cardamom, a spice sold at a very high price. Resin, from the trunk of ‚ÄúKekuna‚Äù is used as water proofing agent. Numerous plants used in the "Ayurvedic" medicine are also collected and sold by the villagers. The stem of ‚ÄúWeniwel‚Äù is a fine example. Timber for house construction is also obtained from trees in and around the Reserve. It is advisable that those who visit the forest be sensitive to the need to conserve it. Create awareness to protect Sinharaja and other rain forests. It is our duty and responsibility as nature lovers. Development of buffer zones can contribute a lot in conserving not only Sinharaja but other forest reserves as well. Construction of hotels and constructions of roads over the protected areas will result in irrecoverable damages. This unique green patch has taken Sri Lanka to the top list of bio diversity rich countries and boosts Sri Lankas tourism and eco tourism. People from all over the world visit Sri Lanka to study, research and enjoy these magical spots and has amazed many wild life and eco experts around the globe. Sinharaja was a highlight of our trip to Sri Lanka.  We spent about 4.5 hours there and could not get there earlier than 10:30am (the full drive from Colombo took about  3.5 hours plus a half-hour stop) so we were only able to do the "short" loop of about 6km.  We took a tuk-tuk from the main road, arranged by our guide/driver, to a small cafe from whence we hiked to the ticket office and then into the rain forest. This is Sri Lanka's last remaining virgin forest and is a UNESCO world heritage site. Because we arrived in the middle of the day we did not get to see the full range of bird or animal life  because their natural activity is limited in the middle of the day; nonethless we heard their calls, which our naturalist often identified for us (hornbill, monkeys, etc.). One of the reasons we loved this hike was because of our naturalist (you cannot hike unaccompanied in the forest both because the government naturally wants to protect the fragile ecosystem but also likely because there are some poisonous snakes around), Sanjaya. He lives in the local village of about fifty families and has extensive knowledge of both the plants and animals at Sinharaja. He was eager to show us (at our request) many of the snakes--including a green pit viper and a bronze back--and reptiles including a couple of hump-nosed lizards and kangaroo lizards. We also saw large milipedes, a giant squirrel at close range, some large fish and a few other things. It was instantly obvious that Sanjaya knows every leaf, twig, nook and cranny of this forest and likewise knew exactly where to look for each kind of creature we wanted to see.  He also pointed out giant vines, wild cinnamon and some other unusual plants, some used for Ayurvedic medicine. Sanjaya was very conscientious and careful, always keeping an eye on our nine-year-old daughter, holding her hand at more difficult points in the hike, carrying her bag when she got too tired, warning us when we should keep our distance from a snake/riverbank/motorbike, etc. The hike was virtually flat and the only challenge was sometimes navigating major tree roots or uneven terrain. Some other reviews mentioned perilous leeches. We saw two miniscule ones, the size of inchworms, between four of us, but that was it the whole time. It was a dry day when we were there so it may have affected things. The short hike does involve crossing a river in order to get to a beautiful waterfall and swimming hole. I did not originally want to do this and ended up not swimming but it was fun to watch the others, who had a great time.
