A great place to visit - leech socks are absolutely necessary and you'll still get plenty of leeches, but what the hey?

We had a simply wonderful day. We stayed at the Eco Villa in Deniyaya, hosted by naturalist guide Bandula Rathnayaka, who led our walk the following day. He showed us so many beautiful plants, birds, insects and reptiles. The lizards were especially beautiful. He took us up to the beautiful little Aranuwa river and to the Lankagama Kekuna Ella Falls, where we swam under the waterfall. On the way back the heavens opened and for 20 minutes we learned why it is called a "rain forest"! ... what an experience! We wouldn't have missed this walk for anything. You do need to wear leech socks or at least, some protection as we all did get a few little 'hitch-hikers'... but not really too much of a problem.

With a very knowledgeable and friendly guide for only two of us (thanks Nimal!), we had an amazing 5 hours easy trek in the middle of a wonderful rain forest. We went for bird watching (we saw about 12 endemic species) but also saw monkeys, snakes, spiders, giant squirrels and plenty of other interesting things such a leaf ant nest and huge spider webs. There are plenty of leeches but not a problem if you wear protective socks (available at the entrance). There were not many tourist so the hike was calm and fun. If you like nature (responsible tourism), this is definitively a place to go. Amazing experience all in all!
Great feeling to explore the forest. You feel so tiny in the tropical rainforest ! Made a 6-hour off-road trip in the forest (excursion done with the Deniyaya National Motel staff).
Superb experience a beautiful place and best to experience with a guide - watch out for leeches - leech socks are available and recommended.
Flippin' awesome. For an extra adventure, enter through the parks remote northern entrance, straight into the heart of the rainforest.

We were disappointed with this trip. We decided to spend a night in the area and therefore took 2 days of our holiday. Although we saw most of the animals we were expecting the 3 hour return trip to the waterfall didn't  live up to expectations. We had expected to be on a trail in the wilderness jungle. Instead we had a pleasant walk alongside the river on a well defined path to the waterfall. The problem was that this path connects 2 villages and is used by motor bikes as a short cut. So instead of peace and quiet we were having to step aside as motor bikes sped past us. So if you fancy a nice guided walk, see some wildlife and a swim by a waterfall then this is good for you but if you're expecting wilderness it is not worth the time out of your holiday.
Excellent guided 3 hour walk through the forest, only saw another two couples and such a varied selection of birds I have never seen before, even a group of Blue Magpies with their insane colouring.

Took a slight detour on our trip for a morning birdwatching in Sinharaja - one has to do it for all the endemics. But annoyingly as a wildlife sound recordist the man on the park entrance refused to let me in with sound recording gear - rather destroying the point of the visit. Apparently I needed a permit in advance from 'Head Office'. He could not show me the rules about this and was quite happy to let photographers in! I cannot understand this irrational discrimination. Other people have been recording there - perhaps he was having a bad hair day.

As we were staying on the coast north of Galle, the drive to Sinharaja took over two hours.  We therefore did not arrive there early enough to see any wildlife or birds.  For those who have seen a rainforest elsewhere in the world, I can only say this is not a particularly attractive or interesting one in comparison to others.  Add to that the presence of leeches and poisonous snakes.  If you go, be sure to purchase the cinnamon oil from the fellow selling it at the entrance.  We heard however he may not always be there or some visitors might not realize what he is selling and rush by him.  We took what we were told by our guide is the normal hike but he did not mention that to get to the falls we would have to wade through the stream with water evidently thigh high.  Being disappointed by then with the hike and knowing we still had over an hour to hike back followed by a two hour drive, we decided not to bother going across the stream.

The reserve is well worth a visit.  You are given a guide who takes you round and is very good at spotting and pointing out the wildlife.  Unfortunately, our guide's English was not the best and we wished we had had one of the other guides whose English was better.  Nevertheless, we had a very interesting visit and saw chameleons, a pit viper, a green snake (can't remember the name), pitcher plants and various birds. We were lucky to spot a group of laughing thrushes just inches from our feet and a bulbul just above our heads.  We also spotted an eagle, but it was not easy to see the birds, so a good pair of binoculars would be handy to take.  We solved the problem of leeches by applying tiger balm to our shoes before we started.  There is a small stall on the way to the reserve with general items and our own guide advised us to buy the balm.  I don't know if the leeches don't like the smell or if the smell cancels out the smell of humans - all I can say is it worked and only cost a few rupees.

We did a 6 hour walk in Sinharaja with a Forestry guide who found some lizards, snakes and birds for us to look at. You have to go with a guide and there were quite a few other groups there at the same time. Everyone seems to do the same route and I don't think it matters whether you do a four hour hike or a six hour one - the itinerary is the same, you just do it slower on the longer hike! Take your swimming gear as there's a chance to swim in a water hole with waterfalls at one point, and a pool where fish clean your feet! I was a bit disappointed with the area the tours go to as it looked as though it was regrowth not virgin rain forest.
Liked Architecture moulded to huge boulders , personal attention friendly service , quite surrounding, simple food served with utmost attention , humour and gentle smile of the hosts .

A fascinating place. There is long rocky drive in the back of an ancient, but well maintained jeep from the park office to the actual entrance - then you are on foot. There are good well-maintained tracks and a great abundance of birds etc to see - although bird spotting in the dense forest can be a challenge. There are lots of lizards and a few other creepy crawlies - notably leeches! It is worth wearing long trousers and closed footwear and purchasing the special leech socks at the entrance! It a privilege to visit the amazing ecosystem.

I booked and paid f$100 USD or a tour with this company called "Best of Lanka", we met another couple who wanted to join us and agreed to pay an additional amount. We were arriving on a cruise ship and were told the name and phone number of the driver and where he would meet us. When we arrived he was nowhere to be found, I borrowed a phone and called the driver who said he had no knowledge of our party and he was in another part of the port and he would phone the company and would get back to me which he did a few minutes later. When he phoned he said he did not have room for 4 passengers so I phoned the company and got no answer so we hired another vehicle. About 45 minutes after we were supposed to be met I get a phone call saying that they had a different driver waiting for us but as we were already in Colombo with limited time available so we would continue and asked the company to let the driver know. When I got back I received an email claiming falsely that I had been told by email to go to a different terminal 2 Km away as the driver was not allowed into the passenger disembarkation area and that I would be considered to be a "no show. I suggested that under the circumstances that a refund was in order and requested that $50 be returned, this suggestion caused another email to be sent and I was told that "company policy" did not allow for refunds. Moral, buyer beware. If you are looking for a city tour and are arriving by cruise ship, there are plenty of cars and vans to choose from, we finished up in a 7 seater air conditioned van with a knowledgeable driver who spoke excellent English for $20 an hour, less money less hassle. TIP, avoid this company and save your money.

We were travelling from Unawatuna to Sinharaja forrest for almost a full day trip. It takes 2 hours to get there, we came around 9:00 and the guide was ready for us. We had a best guide (I am really sorry i cant remember the name), he has been doing a guide there for 6 years, he was able to point at the snakes in the bushes, grab them etc. We started at the restaurant, where you can have some drinks or homemade curries. The guide asked us, how long we want to walk and based on this he planned the way. The journey to the waterfall and back was 3 hours of very slow walk. We saw all different types of animals, 3 different snakes, spiders, chameleons, monkeys, varans, multipedes etc. Do not expect too see interesting flowers, it is a jungle and it is more about the fauna. Practical info: Clothes - would recommmend full shoes, high socks, long pants. There are leeches everywhere, so the guide will put you trousers to the socks, wet your shoes and cover them with a salt. If you are coming in the shorts and flip flops, the guide will put a special repelent on your feet and legs to prevent from the leeches. Even if they do this, the leeches can stick on you. Repelents - good to have good insect repelent Food and drinks - there is a very nice restaurant at the beginning, you can order curries before the jungle trail and they will have it ready for you after you end it (prices are higher) Price - we paid 11 000 rupies for the return journey from Unawatuna and 5000 rupies for the entrance and guide (for 2 people). I think we overpaid it but the guide was really worth it What to bring with you - plasters, if the leech bite you (you will bleed a lot), repelent, camera, swimsuit if you wanna swim at the waterfall, towel (if you are swimming :-) Toilet - there is a very very poor toilet at the beginning, many leeches outside. No toilet on the way The track is not difficult for older people or children

I can only recommend Sinharaja to everybody. Thanks to our incredibly good guide and studied biologist, Bandula, we saw dozens of partly endemic plants & animals: monkeys, snakes, lizards, giant squirrels, birds, mongoose and leeches of course. The tour took around 8 hrs including transport from Deniyaya, but it was not overly demanding as we repeatedly rested at some beautiful waterfalls to have lunch, drink or swim. Come here and contact Bandula: abrathnayaka7@gmail.com or ecovilladeniyaya@gmail.com Bandula speaks perfect English and knows everything about Sinharaja and its myriads of inhabitants. Thank you for a wonderful day!

We liked - we walked for hours in the forest with a forestry guide who could show us the vegetation, wildlife and hidden paths.  We spotted a viper right next to the track, a snake catching fish in a pool, rare colourful birds and the purple leaf monkey. We disliked - the leeches but wore leech repellant socks.

A great walk through the reserve accompanied by a local guide. Our guide lived in the area, and knew the terrain like the back of her hand.  We chose to walk / scramble to the top of the canopy, and whilst this isn't a complex climb, a reasonable level of fitness, good footwear, and leg coverage against leeches is required.  Approx 5 hr walk, taking in some of the lower more easy access sights too.   All worth the effort

if you like getting out and about, or hot and sweaty, a visit to the Forest is for you.  We picked up a Forest guide as required and accompanied by our own excellent guide/driver Prabaht, had a delightful stroll through a patch of primary growth rain forest.  Our forest guide pointed out things of interest, a glorious bright green frog eating viper down by the creek, lizards, spiders, epiphyte orchids, native mango and olive trees as we wandered up the track passing waterfalls and lovely ferns.  We walked for about an hour on a fairly rough track before succumbing to the heat and retracing our steps.  It was a lovely, albeit brief insight into some of the original natural vegetation of Sri Lanka.

We didn't know what to expect. It was a hairy tuk-tuk ride to the start, where we met our guide.  He took us along well-trodden paths, spotting all sorts of creatures that we would have missed (surely they'd been stuck there for him to find!).  There were obviously other such groups being led around too, it's not as 'wild' as you might like.  We wore walking boots, mainly to ward off leaches (guides skip along in flip-flops!).  All fascinating, and I recommend it. The thing that ISN'T explained well enough is the 'waterfall swim' promised at the end.  They tell you to bring swimming stuff.  At a certain spot along the track we were suddenly told to change, and leave all our clothes etc. there so as to cross this river (very swollen in our case).  No real explanation.  Scary crossing of fast river with very slippery rocks.  Then, once on the other side, there's a path to walk to get to the waterfall - in bare feet - across roots and rocks(no idea of how far we'd be going) - about 15 mins probably.  The waterfall pool IS lovely, but the force of the fall is so great that it's difficult to actually swim. Then stagger back, and cross the river again.  Then change back, with other visitors all trying to do the same thing, dripping and uncomfortable.  Then walk back to the beginning. The rainforest treck was great and really interesting.  The swim was less good because of all the awkward, unexplained, changing etc.  They need to let you know what to expect a bit more clearly at the beginning, and then you can choose whether to go through all that or not.

Sinharaja is a world on its own, far from everywhere and ideal for the real nature lovers. Do stay in the Rainforest Eco Lodge, if you dare! an unforgettable experience right in the middle of the jungle

This is the best national park we visited in Sri Lanka. Other than in most park, you can walk along the treks with a local tour guide. The guides are experts in spotting wildlife and makes sure you'll get to see a huge variety of the local fauna & flora. Just makes sure to visit on a dry day, as leeches may give you a hard time on rainy days.

We went to the forest for a 4 hour walk. We were clear we needed a guide in case we got lost but more importantly to tell us about the forest and the forest life and to make sure we had a great and safe experience. And we were so lucky - our guide was Sanjaya Ruwan. He was fantastic - paced the walk to suit our requirements, showed us scary things like a viper in a way that we were and felt completely safe, told us about the forest in ways we really appreciated, and took us to waterfalls where we could swim and enjoy the scene. You can go for a full day walk or even stay overnight - next time we would do this. We really recommend the forest and would suggest if you want to go you call Sanjaya directly as in some cases when hotels organise the visit they seem to take the bulk of the payment leaving very little for the guide. Sanjaya is a qualified guide, works for the forest department - his English was good (and we believe he also has some German and Russian) and with his keen eye we got to see things we never would have. It was fantastic.
Great setting in the rain forest with very comfortable rooms and deluxe accom - relaxing - watch out for the deluges and leeches - I guess that;s what you get in the rain forest.

Galle is a major city in Sri Lanka, situated on the southwestern tip of Sri Lanka, 119 km from Colombo. Galle is the administrative capital of Southern Province, Sri Lanka and is the district capital of Galle District.Travelers are voting Hikkaduwa Beach, Unawatuna Beach and Galle Fort as the best tourist attractions in Galle. Sinharaja rain forest situated 120km south-east of colombo. Is the last extensive stresh of virgin rain forest on the island. Over 11000 hectares, lying across the wet zone at the southern edge of the hill country, sinharaja is an ecological treasure trove. Its staggering array of flora and fauna place among the top bio-diversity hots spot in the world. Over 130 bird species are found hear including many of the 33 species endemic to Srilanka. Sinharaja also home to the elusive leopard, purple faced langur monkey and the giant squirrel. It is preferable to explore Sinharaja on foot which makes for a truly authentic jungle experience. Sinharaja is the seventh UNESCO world heritage site in Srilanka.

We travelled from unawatana approx 2 hrs 30 in a taxi costing 12000 rupees including entrance and guide. We set off around 7am and arrived around 930/10.  The time flies as there is so much to see out the window! We had an amazing day, guide was great, spotted snakes, spiders, Monkeys , camellion to name a few and so friendly and knowledgable. Walk lasted around 4 hours, included breaks and a swim stop at an amazing waterfall which was the highlight of our visit! The time went super fast! Tip. Wear socks if possible as there are leeches but we didn't and the guide had salt for our ankles which is meant to keep them off. Some people were in flip flops which wasn't an issue

we did it in one day trip from matara where we have spent our holiday, there was a nice water fall to spend time, only problem it is very humid with children it was not easy but interesting to see rain forest even if we didn't walk too much inside

We reached here from embilipitiya and it took about 2 hours. The journey was long but it was scenic. At the end we reached the rain forest and found a good guide to take us around for a good price. He was very well knowledgeable about nice little details so it was an excellent day spent. We saw number of water falls and had a swim in one of them which was the highlight of the visit. If you are into nature and appreciate smaller details then this place is for you.
The tour through the forest was one of the many highlights of my trip to sri lanka along with a ~60 minute tuk-tuk ride from Galle. Birds, monkeys, lizards, snakes, aaaand leeches anyone? Wow!

It seems far away from any form of civilization, animals, and many other species, have not yet developed the fear of man, as there is no hunting. advice to those who love taking pictures, especially the birds, go early in the morning, you want to light, you want the temperature to more 'low that it placed animals to take shelter became almost invisible.

The Sinharaja Rainforest trek was the one of the best thing we did on our trip. If you like biodiversity, it's a must. There is a walking path, so no worries about rough hiking. Do bring your hiking boots as it can be wet in some places. There might also be a few leaches. There were so many different kinds of birds, lizards, spiders. It was wonderful being inside the forest. You felt like you were in a different world. Our guide was great and was able to spot all sorts of animals. So many of them were endemic to Sri Lanka. If you like nature, Sinharaja forest is a must!

Also referred as Sinharaja Forest Reserve, the location of the Sinharaja Rain Forest is in the South Western part of the island and covers an area of 11,187 ha (Hectares). Sinharaja Forest Reserve is bordering three districts of the island, namely Galle, Matara and Ratnapura districts. The Rakwana Massif with its mountain ranges are part of the area covered by Sinharaja rain forest. There are few interesting facts on the formation of the Sinharaja Rain Forest in Sri Lanka and how it came in to being. The present rain forests in the world are being an evolution of the earlier rain forests dating back to 150 ‚Äì 200 million years. There had been three strips of large rain forest lands called Amazon, African and Far Eastern at that time. However these large extents of rain forest areas were later became less in area content and were confined to smaller areas. Then about 140 million years back, during the Paleosoic era, a part of land from the Southern hemisphere called Gondwana land, where present day India and Sri Lanka also were situated, started its slow process of separating from the main land. About 55 million years back during Cretaceous era that land mass called Decan plate , where Sri Lanka and India were located separated from the Southern hemisphere , started drifting towards the equator and joined with the Northern hemisphere called Laurussia

The best rain forest in Sri Lanka . Take your time to scroll through. Enjoy the jungle in its own tranquil nature. Your voice will scare away birds.further into the jungle you would see the tallest tree in Sri Lanka. On the way beautiful streams with fishes would treat you, birds will sing you and butterflies guide you.

We certainly had a treat here. Our guide is passionate about his job, writing articles in The British Museum's book about the area. We were lucky enough to accompany him as he released a cobra, which had been caught in a neighbouring village, back into the forest reserve. A once in a lifetime experience!

The rainforest is good, it is a nice forest. But if you want to sea birds, than it is better to walk through the rice fields before the forest. Here you will see more birds than in the forest. We saw not 1 in the forest and we got up very early. But as long as motorbikes come by on the walking path you will not sea birds that much. In the rice fields before the forest, we saw bee-eaters, king fisher birds, eagles and many more beautiful birds. We found also a large monitor lizard on our path.
I have been to many other National Parks in Sri Lanka and visited Sinharaja Forest Reserve for the first time this February and it was truly an awesome experience. Had a very good time there.

While staying at the hotel at the south coast, we went for one day trip to this rain forest. Quite a long journey, but final part was through tea plants with nice views, which we missed on our  way to Nuwara Eliya due to bad weather and fog. Lucky heaving guide Pavel from our hotel, and another local guide who spotted viper, monkeys, endemic birds. We felt safe with them, what was most important aspect. After wading through the river (we should have brought extra shoes - sandals for this) we enjoyed the break at one of the waterfalls. We had to remove couple of leeches, but wearing long leg trousers put into the socks could lower the risk of getting them. They don't represent any health risk. This park is offering lots of alternatives of different entries, walks, and the length of the stay, including accommodation. We really enjoyed this trip, which contributed to our perception how Sri Lanka is country of great diversity. We only hope that the local government will do the best to protect such areas for the future generations.

not a unique rain forest. There are various walks some short some long. Carry water and be sure to choose suitable ones for your fitness level as it becomes extremely hot as the day wears on. The 2km hike to the view point is well worth the effort. Wear gators as there are multitudes of leaches.

Stayed at Rainforest View lodge near the Deniyaya entrance & had a bittersweet experience. While the forest was excellent, the compulsory forestry guide tried to rip us off by charging us triple the published rate for guiding.

This jungle is definitely worth at look at, it's a jungle in Sri Lanka so it's beautiful. I didn't book pre book anything, there is no need, I took a Tuk Tuk with Raja, an amazing, funny and informative man who pointed out stuff on the way and showed me photo opportunities too. Excellent English and also made sure I was charged correctly for water and bananas on the way. I booked him through my amazing hotel fort bliss villa, the manager Arman is also fantastic, take some time to chat with him, extremely interesting. Anyway he can book Raja for your Tuk yuk, he also walked with me and the guide, my guide was provided at the park and you pay 1500rup I also tipped 1000. Raja has a proper tour company and also provides cars too, take a Tuk Tuk it's more fun, easier for photos taking and just a better experience We saw monkeys, lizards, a wonderful waterfall and no other tourists!!! Great day

Great wildlife. Guide spoke no English at all :-( would have paid extra for someone who could talk to us about the rainforest and wildlife. N oone warned us it was 10k up rocky hilly bits, then down again!!

The Sinharaja Rain Forest is spectacular. We saw so many endemic birds, snakes and plants to Sri Lanka. We also got to tick off the Sri Lankan Blue Magpie and Sri Lankan Frogmouth from our "to see" list, which was extremely exciting. An absolutely incredible experience.

We drove about 2 and a half hours from Koggala and then did the 5 km walk to a waterfall. Along the way we saw a green pit viper and a hump nosed lizard. Be sure to take a packed lunch as there is no where to buy food or water. Or local guide was very informative and showed us many of the medicinal plants in the forest. The entrance fee was only 250 rupees each. Although it takes a bit of getting there it is well worth the trip, highly recommended!!

The trip inside the forest was a nice experience. It is after all a rainforest. Unfortunately we did not get the time to search for a good company in advance so we paid 7500rs for the entry. Compared with other sites in Sri Lanka it's a lot. The entry at deniyaya is 560rs so better to go yourself by tuktuk and hire a guide.
This is Amazing place, I think it is like  amazon forest africa.. there is thousands of fauna and floras..../

Between Rakwana and Deniyaya is Suriyakanda, a tiny peaceful town with zero tourists. Morningside is about 7Kms from the town. Originally named by the colonial planters who grew tea on morningside, now it has been replaced by cardamom. Visitors can observe the entire process of cardamom production here. ‚ÄòMorningside‚Äô was so named because it feels like it is morning all day long! The only accommodation seems to be the Forest Dept Bungalow. We walked past a crumbling bungalow which was under construction, and suspect this is the bungalow. There is a much grander private bungalow close by, but the caretaker was very uncomfortable letting us in. ‚Äã A tuk tuk (and definitely a 4WD) with high clearance can go all the way up to the bungalow. But we walked the 7Kms though the tea plantation. What would have been better is to enter the forest itself and explore. However our tuk tuk driver cum trekker was not too happy taking us in to the forest. There is a trail from the Sinharaja Hermitage as well. But beware, there are 2 elephants who roam the area, who are not all that friendly! So, venture very very carefully. ‚ÄãThe villages say they are 15ft at the shoulder and extremely large.

We lived in an ecolodge in the heart of the rainforest and participated two trekking led by local guide. It was nice to walk in the rainforest, but to be honest, it's not so special to us. We love the ecolodge itself better. I've been in Sip Son Panna (Xishuangbanna) of China last May, I find it's a better place if you'd like to visit rainforest,

The forest was so awesome and there are streams and you can have a lovely dip in just to relax and enjoy yourself. The forest is free from urban noise and you only hear the sound of the forest which is entertaining. It's rains most if the time and it's good to be soaked once in a while. Beware of leeches!

If you have not visited this place, then it must be listed in your bucket list. If you are planning to visit, then here are some tips. Ideal period to visit is December to April. Others may have their opinion, but who cares. First travel to the area and put up at a local accommodation spot. I stayed at Sinharaja Adventure Resort. That gives you the chance of starting the hike early, increasing the chances of catching the diverse bird population that roam the forest. There are many treks to take such as the Sinha Gala, translated to Lion's Rock, approx. One day hike. If you are bit more adventures, try a difficult freak going up a creak called Pittakele River towards a waterfall called Duvilli Ella, translated as Dust Falls. Breath taking. Scenic, totally cut off and worth every minute and sweat.
It was nice to walk in the rainforest, but there wasn't anything amazing. We saw some birds and snakes, but there's a path you're following and lots of turists.

We spent one full day in this forest reserve as a family with young children and we all liked it a lot. We booked the tour with our guesthouse and our guide was very helpful. He even helped us to carry our big back-pack. Although we were late in the morning we could see many lizards, spiders, monkeys, snakes and many fishes at the waterfall. The tour to the latter can be recommended for families since it includes a cool swim.

A lot of snakes and lizards. From 6-00 P.M. to 9-00 P.M You can see endemic birds. There are several walking routes. They all are very interesting. One of them runs through the waterfall to the swimming pool where you can swim.

Avoid this company like the plague. In May 2013 I booked two nights in tents in Sinharaja for my family (including two teenage boys). It was to be our Christmas and Boxing Day treat and at over $2000 for two nights, by far the most expensive element of a two week trip.  To put the price into a Sri Lankan context, it cost more per night than renting the luxurious entirety of Taprobane Private Island (five double bedrooms and a private staff). As a family we have done similar 'birding' trips in Africa and South America and safety is paramount when travelling with children. We booked through this company as they seemed to be efficient and provided camps in Yala and other parks too. We knew what sort of thing to expect and not to expect luxury. We were there to see the rainforest and, hopefully contribute to its upkeep as well as the local tourist economy.  We chose to stay in standard tented accommodation as, at the time we booked, the only noted distinction between that and luxury accommodation was the fact that you didn't have a private loo.  At double the price we didn't feel that it was worth it - the website has changed a little since we booked, now offering 3 levels of accommodation. It became clear when we arrived that there was no dedicated vehicle associated with the camp. The company refers to a jeep on their website, we saw no evidence of one.  We had to wait 3/4 hour for a local guy in a pick up truck to turn up to take us into the rainforest (which we had to pay for). I am a fit, active 47 year old, however I twisted my ankle on the steep descent to the camp because there are no steps and we were left to carry our bags. It was wet slippy and dangerous.  We were the only ones staying in the camp. We had confirmed that we wanted a large tent for four (rather than two twos) and this company had confirmed that was available however not one of the small mouldy pod tents fitted that description. The whole atmosphere of the camp was edgy and unsafe. With nobody else there I even felt vulnerable as a woman and that it wouldn't be safe to leave our luggage there during the days. We were promised a guide, however, the (very nice) site manager Mr Kumar informed us that he could take us for a walk that afternoon and he was to be our guide.  He had arrived 3 weeks earlier from Kandy and knew nothing about Sinharaja.  There was no programme of what to visit/ what to see and Mr Kumar asked us what we wanted to do. At that point, we decided to leave.  The most distressing part of the whole experience was actually witnessing the grinding poverty of those who we met on the ground. Not a penny of the vast price we paid filtered to the locals.The thieves in this scenario bask further up the food chain and this is an extremely cynical operation.  Mr Kumar became almost panicky when we decided to go - he was so hungry that he wanted to eat before sorting things out for us and his meal was the left overs of our brief lunch. I spent 20 minutes on the phone to  Mr Janaka, his boss, to confirm that we were not leaving because of anything Mr Kumar had done - because he was scared of what would happen to him.  As we left Mr Kumar pointed out another camp and said that that one was a good one.  Perhaps the other one (on the website) was busy? Perhaps we were unlucky, who knows?  I have corresponded with Sri Lankan Expeditions since returning in the hope of reclaiming some of our money.  I like to give people a chance and I had hoped to be able to say at the end of this sorry tale that we were just unlucky and that this responsible company had reimbursed us some of our costs.  Not a bit of it! I have received two inaccurate, defensive emails and then - nothing. I have no idea whether they provide a good service in other camps elsewhere - but I have no intention of finding out.  AVOID at all costs! Go to Taprobane instead - it's cheaper!

we spend three days close to Sinharaja (@ Pitadeniya Wana Niwahana) Reserve. and it was a mind relaxing place. you will witness beautiful birds, small species (you have never seen before) and trees (older than 400 years). I enjoyed every minute every second inside the reserve. and don't forgot to watch the beautiful waterfalls. If you wanna enjoy Sinharaja like me, please note you really need a good guider. and best time to visit Sinhara is middle of August to end of September. because it is a place that rain will knock you every day (365days). Keep enjoying and love the nature. (NOTE: DO NOT TAKE ANY POLYTHENE  OR PLASTIC INSIDE THE RESERVE) God bless you all to have a lovely time

We had a fabulous day in the forest greatly enhanced by our very knowledgeable guide Bandula Rathnayaka (abrathnayaka7@gmail.com) From practical advice on how to avoid the leeches, an interesting route that included crossing the river on a rope ferry and a swim at the waterfall, to pointing out lots of wild life and interesting trees and plants. The leeches are a nuisance but two pairs of stockings and keeping alert keeps most of them away. A small price to pay for a most interesting day.

Getting there is pretty easy if you leave Colombo at 3.00am yo can be there by 6.30 am and thats the best time to enter the reserve. Most of the local tourists come late thus you have some peaceful time with birds and enjoy as the crowd increases its tough to watch birds. Prefer weekdays to travel and avoid school holiday time. Its the best place in the country to get a good experience of the rain forest. Birds amazing there are so many that you will not see in any other place. Also not forgetting the flora and fauna. Get a tracker they are very nice and will have lot of information about the best spots to see the birds and will direct you well and also they have a good eye for lizards, butterflies and snakes. Accommodation there are a few places around if you want to do overnight stay. also there is accommodation from the wildlife department which you have to book from Battaramulla office. Leeches yes there is plenty you have take your precuations if your not used to them. You can be back in Colombo by 7.00pm so make it a day trip and its fully worth it a must visit.
Nice place to be in the wilderness where there is only Nature and Nature . The trip in the morning was mind blowing with sights and sounds very soothing and exciting.

Wear at least 2 pair of tights, covering your t-shirt. Spray both clothes and free parts of body with moskito spray. Continuously monitor all parts of your body as the leeches will still be able to make it on you - once discovered, remove asap!!!

but It never rained in the Sinharaja rainforest that day, & the leeches didn't get me either - what luck eh?  This was just as well as the only footwear I took for this trip was pair of 30 year old Dunlop wellies, & my flip-flops :-/  I didn't want to take my good boots, & I couldn't find any good walking comfy boots to buy before I left for my holz, hence the wellies.  OK, So my poor old faithful wellies were laughed out of the forest as totally unsuitable, so I went with the flip-flops.  We arrived with sun tours in the posh car but the road to the forest wasn't suitable to go any further, so we had to use the tuk tuk to go the rest of the way. This was quite exciting as the road was not a road as such but a rather a bumpy ol' ride, I prayed that we wouldn't get tossed over the edge, & seeing as the driver was very good my prayers were answered.  We were introduced to Sarath who was to be our guide for the next few hours, he was brilliant as he actually carried my husband's very heavy camera rucksack for the whole of that time!  My husband had unfortunately hurt his leg & couldn't walk very well, but it wasn't a problem as Sarath took us on a nice easy route (there are many different ones).  So if you do have mobility probs you can still do the forest.  It was a nice walk, & we weren't too hot, wet, or sucked to death by leeches.  We saw monkeys, giant spiders, snakes, birds, lizards, water monitors, & a millipede, we weren't disappointed.  Why has no one on TripAdvisor ever mention the 'I'm A Celeb Get Me Outta Here' bridge?   Poor Sarath practically had his hand & arm ripped off as I clung to him for dear life, moaning & whinging ever step across the swinging bridge.  I lived to tell the tale & I'm so proud of me! We bumped in to some  German & French people on our way through the forest & stopped to chat, the leeches had got the french man, so they were there!  Actually we did see one leech but it was dead, so there's more proof of their existence.  We stopped off to rest once we'd gone across the bridge & there was lots of info & specimens to look at, a toilet too.  Unfortunately we didn't get as far as the waterfall as I'm afraid of water (you're expected to go in up to your waist) & my husband's leg was too bad for this.  We did however watch Sarath take a dip in the river, which we could've  done too if we'd been up to it.  Then we turned back & a lovely meal awaited us at Sinharaja View Villas Restaurant, oh how I love that Devilled Chicken!  It wasn't expensive & they served us ice cold Coke, not something I'd usually drink but it's good in hot countries.  They were lovely people & made us very welcome indeed, actually I'd've loved to have stayed there for a few days.  Next time maybe!

We travelled far to get here. I love rainforests and though Mulu was quintessentially the best for us, we wanted to experience this one. Not wanting to go on 3,000rps trip from lodging with guide who is a bit of a self professed rainforest guru around these parts, we made our own way so we could turn back any time we needed to. We heard it is rough, leach infested and slippery. We made our own way there by bus from Deniyaya - about 10km until the road gets so rough it has to be covered on foot. The tuk tuk  from the bus can take you so far but it lurched violently about huge mud filled potholes until the road narrowed to a path and we got off. We declined the offer of guides and walked on arriving at the ticket hut with no-one in it and the side door locked. We walked on thinking we would pay the entry fee at the information centre 1 or 2 kms along the river trail. 200m along the way, we were accosted by two men on a motor bike who demanded we return to the empty ticket hut and pay our dues. We said no-one was there and we were happy to pay but why did we have to turn back. They insisted and looked threatening. We had breached some protocol or other and with leech attached, returned to the hut now open with a stroppy woman demanding we pay  and the Guide with two customers in tow yelling from behind that I had broken the law and the police would be after me as I entered the park without paying. I told him I'd gladly oblige if someone had been in attendance. I challenged the woman who when pressed said she had gone to the toilet. I went to pay the entry fee and then was told to pay for a guide but I wanted to go only as far as the information centre and not the 4 hour treck to the waterfall. This is Sri Lanka and they do things their way global commons  Unesco rainforest reserves or not!  Other places like Sigirya we have the option of a guide and I was not expecting it to be forced on me here. Like some museums. Today in Galle, I paid 300rps to enter the maritime museum and when I went to take a photo, I was sent back to the desk to pay another 300rps. It is all very confusing and seemingly unregulated!

My actual visit was well before stated date. Ideal for those who like to see species of tropical rain forest vegetation. Be prepared for plenty of leeches by using ample amounts of insect repellent. Long walk up to the top. Not motorable or accessible by wheel chair. You are unlikely to be disturbed as only the enthusiats go there.

Went to Sinharaja from Deniyaya side where the experience was unmatched. We stayed at this unique place called Rainforest Eco Lodge which had rooms made out of steel container boxes. During the night it's very cold & cozy. We ventured into the rainforest at around 2.30pm & took an off road route. It was a really adventurous journey since we had to climb up & down  holding on to the roots & the trees. The forest bed was slippery from the overnight rain & we fell down a couple of times (with no injuries) due to our muddy feet. Surprisingly there were very few leeches in this area. We came to a couple of virgin waterfalls which were out of this world. It was really refreshing to see something like this in the middle of no where. The waterfalls are yet to be named since only a handful of people have ever seen them. Birding opportunities were plenty but since I wasn't a hardcore birder, I didn't pay my full attention to them, but kept on admiring the nature's beauty.

Some one who is holidaying in Galle or close to Galle the best option is to visit Sinharaja Rain forest is from Deniyaya.Its about one and a half hour drive (50)km to Deniyaya and you turn off right infront of Deniyaya Police station to left and travel about 9 Km to Mederipitiya from Mederipitiya town have to travel about 7 Km to the forest entrance.One who can reach the entrance in the morning can do the walk in to the forest (Guided Tour with a lisenced Guide will cost around 600 Rupees Per Person) and come accross about 5 beautifull water falls easily in addition to the 40/50 M high trees,birds,lizards butterflies and  snakes.Its a nice way to complete the day by having a dip in one of  those cristal clear water falls and feel that you are part of that beautifull world out there.

I had a great experience. Took a local bus from Hikkaduwa to Aluthgama to Matugama to Kalawana to Kuduawa village. Kuduwa village is at the nortern section of the forest. The journey took me around 6 hours and I had to change buses 4 times but it was a great journey. Then I took a nice long (30 minutes) trip on a diesel filled jeep to go up 2 km to Martin's lodge and then began the action. I am an avid traveller and very fond of the jungles. Having gone to a number of them around this region, I found the jungles of Singharaja to be similar to those in Periyar National Park in Kerala, India. However, these are raw jungles which shall command your respect. The trees are around 50mts tall. I must have seen around 40 different species of birds. On day 1 I walked down to the reserve's office, took a guide and walked with him into the jungles. The walk starts at around 0830 hrs and continues till around 1300 hrs. You can tip the guide about 200Rs. The jungles are very thick and so the visibility is not more than a few feet at many occasions. Small streams flow around and the jungles are chirping with birds and monkeys (the monkeys, purple faced, aren't comfortable coming close to the people). There tend to be leeches but I carried a pocket knife, kept checking my boots and must have removed around 15, though 2 managed to get me (for around 2 minutes each). I think the leech socks arent really that required. The guide wears flip flops! Carry binoculars if you want to see the birds (which you should). Carry water, though the spring water in the taps is perfect, forget the bottled stuff. Ensure you don't visit the jungles during the rainy season. It pours in this place in the summers! I took a nice long walk into the village on the second day. Saw lots of birds (albeit slightly common) and saw the gentle village life. Drink a cup of tea at the main square and buy some palm jaggery locally made. The people, as in other parts, are lovely. Especially if you stay at Martin's lodge. Enjoy

It is better to walk with tour guide. We can ask from tour guides to 1000 Rupees. Also they having vast knowledge about that. Not only but also sinharaja in one of a world heritage. Good vegitation and many water falls there.I like kakuna water fall. I had a bath also there. Pure and cool water coming from top of the forest. better you bring something to eat and drink without plastics. NICE FOREST i HAVE EVER BEEN.

The sheer, astounding diversity of the plants. The smells. The kangaroo lizards. The birds. The 43-metre high tree soaring, it seemed, into the clouds. The butterflies. A 3-hour escape into a different, green, peaceful world, the only sounds the sounds of nature.

We went to rainforest by car from Mirissa. We had also guide trough forrest (Sinharaja rest guesthouse - Bandulla), so he told us a lot of info about local flora and fauna there. The guide was a bit expensive (4000 rupees per person exc. entrance) but he was worth it. It was a great adventure - we were swimming in waterfall, walking trought forrest, trying to get rid of leeches:) Totally awsome and highly recommended.

It's a long windy slow road to get to this remaining pocket of rainforest which has been saved from being cut down for cultivation. We saw a few lizards and some endemic birds but by and large we were disappointed with our visit which was principally up and back along a wide track with a detour loop to see an old large tree. Our guide didn't seem particularly interested in much beyond avoiding leeches. Unless you are a keen birder wanting to seem some rarities, I wouldn't go out of your way to visit.

The track leading up to the forest is very rough and the jeep ride can be a bit hairy but once you leave the vehicle the experience is breathtaking. Our tracker was absolutly superb, he found us most of the birds we wanted to see and he didn't even have binoculours.

Early rise !! 5.30 wake up for 6am pick up to Sinharaja rain forest.  It was organised by Boulder Garden hotel we stayed. We got on the jeep with breakfast picnic's and drove 1hr to entrance. Paid fees and got the tracker Sunil, then we had our breakfast and started the trails at 7.30 am . It was bit chilly and dam but beautiful sunny day...well it's a rainforest. First trail was easy flat surface, we saw lot s of birds, rare trees and streams. Then we went on the Giant Nawada Tree trail. Wow what a giant tree it was. Then we took Halmandiyadola trail and Mulawella trails. Finally we ended up on top of this giant rock (767m high)! It was hot and the scenery was out of this world. There was a huge group of school kids following us to the top of the rock too! We spent some time own top admiring the views that stretched to Kalutara, Galle & Matara etc. Sunil our tracker took us back down thru a very rarely used trail (Mullawella) it was very rocky, wet n slippery. Lots of leaches climbing up your feet. More than anything you had to concentrate on the your feet and my trainers were so slippery. I was so glad when we reached ground level without breaking a leg !!!! A nasty leach was sucking my blood out and Sunil pulled it out but kept bleeding. It was past 12.30, We decided not to go into Rakwana. We headed back to Boulder Garden instead for lunch. We reached hotel around 13.30, got some vodka & orange and headed towards pool, we ordered lunch and had a nice dip and swim in the pool to cool down. We have never been to the rainforest before and this was a dream come true!!!! Can't wait to do the morning side entrace next! We will recommend this adventure anyone who loves nature!!!! http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sinharaja_Forest_Reserve

we spent 4 hours in the forest with our guide who was very knowlegeable and passionate, aftter around 2km there is an awesome waterfall that you can swim under and jump off. lots of different wildlife, many endemic to sri lanka. we stayed at Deniyaya guest house and paid 5000rp for tuk tuk and guided tour of the forest

leaches!!! you need a good insectacide to prepare your clothes and yourself the leache socks promised wer not available. Our guide although experienced didn't really see anything more than we did!! It was disappointing a walk in the forest, pleasant but not much better!

Sinharaja rain forest is a tropical rain forest which is kept as the home of many indigenous species of wildlife in sri lanka. we entered from the kudawa entrance. our point was mulawella peak and we reach their in 3h, if any one needs to go to sinha gala peak ( 10 km ) it should start at the morning.

Our drive to Sinharaja was a memorable one, but not in a good way. The roads to Sinharaja takes a while to say the least i the hilly terrain. On top of thet there were civil works on the road and big rains had made the roads very cumbersome indeed. So, do not expect the ride there to be smooth. We arrrived at our logde 22.... the plan was aournd 18... Anyway, once there Sinharaja was a really nice place. We did not see any mammals (except for humans) at all. We did see a few birds including Jungle fowl, lots of snakes and lizards, butterflies and fish. Along with trees and flowers. And leeches, that we did not manage to avoid. Two out of five got bitten. We survived that though. Beautiful views in a dense forest. Our guides were magic. I cannot understand how they did it when they spotted the snakes.

It will easily take away your half day if you love nature. Brush up your knowledge on ferns and flora, the butterflies, the birds, the snakes, the mushrooms... and you will love it here! We had a great time here... We saw many beautiful butterflies, giant moths, keelback snake, green pit viper, and another small snake! The mushrooms are unique and in great variety here... The ferns are beautiful and rare... In all an awesome experience! Thanks to our guide Chandra! Best time to go would be in Jan end mornings.

A wonderful experience, very well preserved rainforest. Its around a 4.5km walk you might choose for a longer or a shorter walk. Its a experience full of nature don't expect huge scary animals, you would mostly spot lizards (monitor too), snakes(we saw the green pit wiper :)), birds, lots of butterflies, wild plants, insects and many more. The tour guides here are mostly volunteers so giving them tip is a good idea. Specifically ask for a english speaking guide if you need one.

Very long drive to reach with the road not being the best. We had organised for a jeep safari and it is quite a bashing ride into the park. We just blundered into the walk while there were much better prepared tourists around us with long socks to ward off leeches. But we had a great guide who gave me a stick with chewed tobacco tied on the edge of it to push away any leeches that get too comfortable. Apparently leeches dont like tobacco :) Not much animal life but some lovely butterflies and bird sounds and tall beautiful trees in the primary forest.

Visiting was worth it, but it was a 3 hour taxi drive from Galle and then a 45 minute tuk tuk drive up a very pot holed road.  We then walked for 4 hours and saw 5 beautiful water falls and swam in the last one. It is not an easy walk so be in shape if you go. Not a huge amount of animal life to see but the scenery was fabulous.  Visited December 2012 - cost us for 2 people - taxi, tuk tuk, entrance fee - 15,000 rupies - 500 rupiee tip for the guide - who was very good.  200 rupiee tip for tuk tuk.  500 tip for taxi driver.

Lots of different animals and insects to see. We saw florescent green little snake and held it :) We've also seen monkeys, different species of lizards, some weird caterpillars, spiders, and some amazing plants... To top it off there's a swim at the waterfall at the end, a beautiful day out in beautiful Srilankan nature.

We were going the 'wrong' way round Sri Lanka, and were coming from the south.  From deniyaya it was a question of asking around.  We eventually gave up driving when the road got too rough,and got a very daring tuktuk to the entrance.  Even so it was a good 1hour journey from deniyaya to the entrance. No signposts, and rubbish road.  Once inside the park a guide showed us round and it was interesting, but not amazing.

Sinharaja rain forest is Sri Lankan famous and biggest rain forest. Normally there are three main entrance for that rain forest. Galle district - Neluwa Matara district - Deniyaya, Pallegama entrance Ratnapura district - Kalawana, Weddagala We went to Sinharaja forest at Pallegama entrance in Deniyaya. It is very adventures tour. Ideal for birds watching, walking and relaxing. We can see many waterfalls (ex -Kekuna waterfall) Climate The average annual temperature of Sinharaja is approximately 23.6C. It annually receives more than 2500mm of rainfall. There fore no dry spell throughout the year. Sinharaja forest is our heritage we must protect this our invaluable world heritage rain forest.
Well it was a wonderful experience of tropical flora and fauna, if u wannna get a experience of a rain forest Sinharaja is the best.

Sinharaja Forest was on my wishlist since we started to plan our trip to Sri Lanka. I never visited a rainforest before, so I was really looking forward to it. We booked the trip in our hotel, so they took care of the transport by tuktuk (otherwise we never find the entrance to the forest I suppose) and a guide (without a guide, you can't get in). We arrived in the afternoon, wich is apperently not the best time to watch the birds. Fortunatly we saw enough other animals to compensate the abscense of the birds. For example we saw chameleons, monkeys, a giant centipede, a big waspnest, a little green snake... First we thougt our guide was quite laid-back, but he was more alert than he looked and spotted a lot of animals. He told us about the vegetation and helped me also to remove the leaches from my legs. We had to cross a river and ended the tour by a nice waterfall. It was a shame we didn't know that, otherwise we had brought some swimmingclothes and towels. After having lunch, we had to take the same path back. After all it was a very nice experience, but I do regret it was such a short trip. We were lucky to be there in low season, it must be less special with lots of tourist around.

Had a awesome trip to Sinharaja where you and mother nature meet and great each other. Natural pure spring water and clean oxygen with beauty of its own. Stayed there for 2 days and will go again in the near future. Miss it so badly. We stayed at a wonderful eco lodge and the owner Mr. Anil is very friendly and supportive. Food was lovely and the service was simply superb.

We had a really nice walk in the rain forest. Unfortunately for us the weather wasn't so good and we didn't get to see any birds in the reserve (though we saw several kingfishers in the paddy fields on the way to the reserve). We did get to see a couple of snakes, lizards and spiders. Leeches are a problem but if you keep rubbing salt around your shoes you should be fine. Another option would be to walk in your flip flops and shorts, which we saw our guide do successfully and without any problems. Carry water and snacks.

We spent a very good morning walking in the rain forest with our guide. I would have liked to go off the track a little but we did see some great animals. The motobikes going up and down the path is a little odd. I missed out on the swim in the waterfall pool as i was feeling a little down as i was lunch to four leeches and my left leg was still bleeding and covered in blood. Get yourselves there and spend 1/2 a day. I would have liked the guest house where we were staying to offer a different walk, as we would loved to done two walks.
We stayed at Martin's Lodge, simple but ideal for its forest surroundings and Martin is very knowledgeable about the area. Take guided walks into the forest.

If you feel like Indiana Jones or Tarzan wandering in the Jungle, this is the place to go for a stroll !! More than walking in a lush vegetation, you'll have the opportunity to spot many animals including giant squirrels, water monitors, monkeys, snakes (cobra, green pit viper, hump-nosed viper), mangoose,fish, porpucines, civets, kingfishers... and there is no doubt you'll be spotted by leeches which are abundant in the forest and which are waiting for passing-by mammals  to suck blood. it may help to carry a little bit of salt to get rid of them on the way. And don't forget that in the Rainforest, it usually... Rains a lot!! Thus, it may not be a luxury to bring a raincoat in addition to your camera. Enjoy,

Usually wen I go to visit the Singaraja forest I rent a Bike in Hikkaduwa , start very early in the morning (arnd 5.30 am) and with a confortable & easy drive arrive arnd 8 am. Amazing views on the way...once you ll reach Deniyaya find a guide and spend all the day in the forest. Nice waterfall, snakes, huge trees etc. be sure to have some salt with you : leaches will not bite if you ll spread some salt on your feet and legs. It is possible to spend the night in the forest bungalow (a bit expancive but nice) ..you have to book in advance trough the forest department. By the way from Hikkaduwa to the forest is 120 kms....

If you really like rainforest then this is a good place to go. Particularly if you are interested in the flora. It is a bit away from the usual tourist haunts but is very important as suggested by its world heritage status. Didn't see much wildlife other than a few butterflies and there certainly are no stunning views. Also be prepared for the leaches.

If you‚Äôre willing to go to  sinharaj forest , the best may be not to make a one day trip , if you can book a bungalow inside the forest ,through Forest Conservation department, that would be ideal (But please not you have to take all provisions ,they only cook and give you the food), their you can have a bath in the river in the morning and evening , walking in the forest during the day time, that makes it a very special palace , there are  about 7 waterfalls to visit within the forest ,but the route it bit tough. You have to take leech replicate also, I was there  last week for 3 day trip and I enjoyed a lot, if you travelling  from deniyaya side you have to walk 1.5Km to the bungalow ,parking the vehicle at a nearby place, a car cannot travel on this road ,so it‚Äôs better if u can hire VAN  with good clearance.

Sinharaja forest was one of the great disappointments of our trip to Sri Lanka. Forest road is very long and does not justify the trip. Walking is the large, central pathway, did not enter into the forest. We were there three hours and barely saw a few lizards, two orchids and monkeys that were very far away. Plants was not special. There was not really anything special. If you want tosee a rain forest go somewhere else ... Visiting friends advised us to give up, but we heard about the place and we thought maybe they are wrong and we were disappointed to discover they were right. Maybe a day trip there can be seen more things?

Why Sinharaja ? Means Lion-King (Sinha- Raja) . The Forest spread over the districts of Ratnapura, Galle and Matara. Rainforest spread over 100,000 hectares of the south western hills and lowlands. this forest represents a tropical rain forest with dense tall trees, steep and rugged hills and rivulets. The value of forests such as Sinharaja are well known for their functions as watersheds and store houses of great biological wealth. We access through the Deniyana (From Galle) also you can access Kalawana (Via Ratnaupura - Vaddagala) There are many circuit bungalows at the both ends udawa and deniyaya. There are trackers you can hire for your jounery through the forest. I recommend you go with Naturalist...
Don't miss it if you are of any biological tendencies. Try to take morning AND evening sessins. They differ...

We had a nice day out at the sinharaja rain forest. The trip up there from Bentota was great in itself. Going through towns/villages/jungle areas. The rain forest is amazing with low cloud over the jungle. We saw frogs, snakes, monkeys,various birds, spiders etc. Quite a bit of walking involved but on a pathway so nothing too difficult. Leeches were sorted out with a covering of tiger balm on our uncovered feet etc. We were taken round by a very informative guide. The forest has a lovely damp hunid atmosphere and is very lush with lots of small rock pools.etc. Well worth a visit.
Amazing location with good paths and an amazing variety of rare and unusual birds

We visited with a group in early March.  Palitha, the ranger, is incredibly knowledgeable and helpful.  The park has a station with accommodation (which we used) or you can stay in a homestay with one of the local families.  We saw so much wildlife - dozens of birds, various vipers, a cobra, lizards, numerous insects, etc.  We did the ten hour hike up the mountain.  The trail is used so infrequently that they had to go the day before and groom it for us - building small log bridges and ladders where necessary.  It was so great to hike and explore during the daytime, and then sleep to the sound of rushing water and insects at night.  There's a nice river with a beach right beside the station.  It's worth at least a few days if you're in Sri Lanka. The only downside is the abundance of leeches.  Even with long pants and leech socks, I was attacked very day.  They'd crawl through the smallest holes in clothing.
The forest has a magiclal atmosphere.  Don't go in a large party
I recommend here. Really there is an important part of Sri Lanka‚Äôs nature.

I didn't go to sinharaja but I really wanted to so I'm leaving a review as to why i didn't. Look away now if you don;t like people whinging about costs ..... As some reviews have said here, sinharaja i a great spot for jungle walks and an opportunity to visit unspoilt forest. The entry fee, plus the cost of a mandatory guide meant that I didn't get to see Sinharaja nor did I get to see any of the national parks of sri lanka for the same reason.  Why do tourists have to fork out $80 for a guide and car to visit national parks whilst locals pay just Rs30?? I wish that foreign tourists would boycott the national parks of SL in protest at the stupid money-grabbing pricing. ha, fat chance of that happening hey!?

Excellent birdwatching, with so many of Sri Lanka's endemic species in Sinharaja. Our park guide was very good - knew his birds and worked very hard looking for the specialties like Sri Lankan Frogmouth and Seredip Scops Owl. We had 2 days in the park and loved it. The sheer variety of wildlife and plant life is fantastic and Sinharaja is unique in many ways. To watch the mixed feeding flocks of birds pass through makes the trip worthwhile. Yes, there are leeches, but the leech socks available from he park work well. All part of the adventure!
Nice walk of +/- 4 hours in the forest with a guide but we didn't see many birds. A few snakes, little chameleons and colourful butterflies.

UNESCO World heritage site. One of the last tracts of virgin rain forest in Sri Lanka. Possibly best location to track endemic birds. Also great place to see endemic reptiles and plants. Visitors pl note its "rain forest" read leeches by the dozen!!! one has to walk here, no jeep safaris! Serious photographers, think hard about your lens choices.

i loved this place. lots of pitcher plants, butterflies, incredible birds (including a frogmouth), reptiles (including green vine snake, which was beautiful), wild orchids, well-maintained trail. HOWEVER: USER BEWARE. There are tons of leeches. You can either go in flip flops and that way you'll see them or wear your socks, which they can go through. I wore socks and shoes, because i'm not used to walking on forested trails in flip flops. I got 8 leeches and my socks and shoes were FULL of blood. And the bites continue bleeding for hours and hours afterwards. It was really kind of gross, but also kind of cool in a weird way. So if you're really squeamish about creepy crawlies, perhaps not the best activity for you.

Located in the south west of srilanka. sinharaja is a national park and a bio diversity hot spot which was declared as a world heritage site by UNESCO. it is of international significance and has been designated a world biosphere reserve in 1978. in hilly virgin rain forest which is part of the countries lowland rain forest Eco region was saved from the worst of commercial logging by its inaccessibility .the reserve is 21 km from east to west and a maximum of 7 km from north to south and is a treasure trove of endemic species, including trees,insects,amphibians ,reptiles,birds and mammals.

The Sinharaja rainforest is certainly worth a visit - while quite different from what we expected, it is a unique experience and great place. The forest itself can be entered from multiple places - we took the norhtern entrance so situation may be little different in other places. Be aware that in addition to the entrance fee you have to pay for a mandatory guide (you cannot enter by yourself). The guide is one for a group and it is not as expensive as it may seem - we paid less than two thousand rupees for the entrance for two persons, everything included. The quality of your visit is highly influenced by the quality of your guide - be sure to check that he AT LEAST speaks in your language well. While we were lucky and ended up with an experienced guide that told us a lot of interesting information and knew local plants and animals well, others were not - we met a Swiss group who had a much less usefull young boy who mostly smiled and did not talk much. The trip consist of a roughly three hour walk through a well traveled path and then of a short walk through a small path taking you into the heart of the forest. The length is very variable depending on your speed and on your curiosity. You will mostly see flora - lot's of trees, flowers, orchids, shrubs, lianas and other green things. Don't expect too much fauna - while the forest is densely inhabitated, the animals are shy and mostly run away from the tourist paths. We saw mostly snakes, lizards, birds, butterflies, millipedes, squirrels, spiders and catterpillars (and also a behinds of a bunch of running monkeys). Don't expect any of the "more interesting"animals like monkeys, leopards and tarantulas because they are hidden in the middle of the park and even the guides see them rarely. Last tip: come prepared. Long trousers are a MUST as well as long socks and firm footwear. The small paths are filled with leeches and while they are not as bad as it sounds, it's better to avoid them. (They are small worms, not even one inch long, they are living on ground on wet areas and stick to your shoes and then crawl up. They can crawl throuh small holes in shoes, socks and trousers. They stick to your skin - it does not hurt and you won't even notice and you can just pull them off - they will leave a small bite. They are not dangerous in any way though, so do not be paranoid :)

We went to the park with a local guide and before we started we put salt in our socks to prevent leeches to get us. We forest very beautifull place. With water falls and pool where we can swin. An all day program and very interresting. But at we need to lock for the leeches all the and take them off. This spoil a little bit our pleasure.

I took a 3 hour tuk-tuk from Mirissa on some of the worse roads I have been on only to be informed that I must hire a guide to take a walk in the park. The guide was clueless. A little while later I saw 3 men just past the bridge to the village by the rangers station. They were dynamite fishing and the people running the park didn't care. Hard to considerate it a world heritage site with that kind of activities going on.

column11: Nature in its true form. Nothing has been altered to attract more tourists. Not even road signs. The experience was truly breathtaking & unique. A Trek through a virgin rainforest without the fear of being attacked by wild animals. There‚Äôre many areas in Sinharaja that no human being has set foot on. Nobody ventures that deep into the rainforest. The tree growth got thicker & thicker as we went in. These are the moments that defy all the other experiences in our lives. No human contact, no mobile coverage, no nearby hospitals, but only the sound of the insects & the deep darkness of the forest in a sunny afternoon. Old sinhala legends claim that the forest was royal territory belonging to ancient kings & in some early colonial records, the rainforest is referred to as the ‚ÄúRajasinghe Forest‚Äù We stopped only for a little rest at times, since we had lots of ground to cover. But the amount of time dedicated for certain beauties of the nature was priceless. The variety of the vegetation was exquisite. The further we ventured into the forest, the distance between two trees got closer. There‚Äôre some parts of the forest where we couldn‚Äôt see more than 20 feet ahead. Sinharaja is filled with birds, butterflies & snakes. I was fortunate enough to witness several of their kind. If you enjoy the natural bio-diversity, this is the best place to be in Sri Lanka to study about them. there's a research center inside the forest as well. There're no wild animals except for a couple of wild elephants who're rarely seen.

We have been twice to Sinharaja now and we are so looking forward to going back. I can not give you any technical details about the place, (but i see that the person who wrote the previews review did a great job) but i can tell you what its like for an outsider to visit this place. We drove to Sinharaja  early morning, after driving through some beautiful hills full of tea plantations, we arrived at the entrance. The entrance fee to the forest is around 600Rupees per person  and we had our video camera with us so we had to pay an extra fee for it, but trust me, its totally worth it.  it all came down to around 10 euros for the both of us plus the cost of the guide. Let me start by saying that the best time to visit this place is from January to April, when its dry season so there is no rain. The first time we went to Sinharaja it was May 2008, and it was rainy season so there was the huge problem of Leeches, which we had heavily underestimated and we just went there in our shorts and sandals. From the moment we went in to the forest,  every ten minutes we would be wiping off Leeches from our legs and cleaning the blood, you have to know that when leeches start sucking your blood you dont feel a thing, when they stop thats when the blood starts to flow and you realize that you have been bitten.  its really scary but fortunately u dont catch anything from them. u just bleed for a few minutes thats all. This time we went it was dry season so there werent so many leeches, but we went prepared anyways, rubber boots and track pants so there were a couple of desperate leeches who were looking for a way to get in the boots. But anyways, always go prepared. The guides that accompany you are really great.  they speak english and they will tell you everything you want to know and the names of every single animal and insect, and even the names of every single tree. We saw so many beautiful butterflies that were so huge that at first we thought they were birds. We also saw lots of beautiful birds, many of these you find only in Srilanka. and many different species of Lizards, some very rare Animals as well, like the Frog Mouth Owl which was so amazing to see. lots of snakes, water snakes and if you are lucky, you may see some wild cats. If you are a Nature lover, or if you love hiking or u just love watching those documentries about rainforests and always wanted to visit one, well this is the place for you.
